{{for|the theologian and author|Malachi Martin}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{short description|Australian murderer and suspected serial killer}} {{Infobox serial killer |name = Malachi Martin |image = |caption = |birthname = Malachi Earl Martin |alias = |birth_date = 1831 |birth_place = [[Willunga, South Australia]], [[Australia]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1862|12|24|1831|df=y}} |death_place = [[Adelaide Gaol]], [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]], [[Australia]] |cause = [[Hanging]] |parents = Michael Martin
Mary Martin |conviction = [[Murder]] |sentence = [[Death]] |victims = 2–5 |beginyear = 1856 |endyear = 1862 |country = [[Australia]] |states = [[Adelaide]] |apprehended = June 1862 }} '''Malachy Martin''' (also '''Malachi Earl Martin''') (c.1831 – 24 December 1862) lived in [[South Australia]] in the 19th century and was convicted and executed for committing a willful murder in 1862. Although in most official records his given name is written as “Malachi” it is clear that his parents actually gave him the traditional Irish form of the name, popularised through the veneration of St. Malachy, a twelfth-century Bishop of Amagh.Martin’s marriage certificate shows this spelling, while on that certificate he signed his name “Malacky” (1858 marriage certificate indexed by Births, Deaths and Marriages South Australia at Book 317, Page 541). On his petition to the Governor in December 1862 Martin signed his name “Malaky Martin” (Malachy Martin’s petition to the Governor & Executive Council of South Australia, GRG 24/6/1862/1215). In oral tradition the name is pronounced in a way that indicates it should be spelt “Malachy” rather than the Biblical “Malachi”. John Bowyer Bull, who had met Malachy, mentions him in his memoirs, and although he spells the name several ways, they are all closer to “Malachy” than to “Malachi” (J.B. Bull, unpublished manuscript ''The Life of John Bowyer Bull, The Australian Bushman & Explorer, 1838-1894'', PGR 507/3, pp 62-65). ==Early life== Martin grew up around the [[Willunga, South Australia|Willunga]] district, south of [[Adelaide]] and in 1844, just before he turned 13, he was charged with theft while working at a post office at the settlement at [[Encounter Bay]].Southern Australian, 5 July 1844 He was tried at Adelaide but found not guilty. Six days later, his mother, Mary, died in strange circumstances by drowning in a pond near the family farm. Although all witnesses stated that they had not observed anything to cause them to question her state of mind, the inquest into her death found that she had committed suicide “while labouring under temporary insanity" due to her distress over her son's criminal trial. Her death was made even more tragic because she was heavily pregnant at the time.Southern Australian, 19 July 1844. ==Death of William Robinson== A few years later, Martin moved to his father's new pastoral lease near the [[Coorong]]. Martin also worked as a mail coach driver from Encounter Bay to [[Kingston SE, South Australia|Kingston SE]] and [[Naracoorte, South Australia|Naracoorte]]. At the time this was the only [[Princes Highway|main road]] from Adelaide to [[Melbourne, Victoria|Melbourne]]. While living in the area, he became friends with William and Catherine Robinson, who ran an inn, the ''Traveller’s Rest'' at [[Salt Creek, South Australia|Salt Creek]], a small settlement along the Coorong. It was later believed that Catherine and Martin were having an affair which was to have fatal consequences. On 14 June 1856, William Robinson's body was discovered with his throat cut. Martin was a suspect, but was never charged with his murder. Several weeks later, he moved to [[Sydney]] for two years before returning to South Australia and marrying Catherine on 23 June 1858. ==Murder of Jane Macmanamin== A young woman named [[Jane Macmanamin]] was working at ''Traveller’s Rest'', but in February 1862 she disappeared. Although Martin stated she had moved away on a whim to the [[Mount Gambier, South Australia|Mount Gambier]] area in the colony's south east, in April 1862, Jane's sister, who had constantly stayed in contact with her, sent a letter to the police in Adelaide, suspicious because she had not heard from Jane in some time. This matter was being investigated by Lance Corporal William Rollison from the [[Wellington, South Australia|Wellington]] police station.State Records (South Australia) GRG 5/2/1862/1740, enclosure 510 On 29 May, a Ngarrindjeri local, "Micky", told William Allen of Woods Wells (11 miles — about 18 kilometres — north of Salt Creek) that a fellow Ngarrindjeri by the name of Itawanie had found Jane's body hidden and partially buried in a [[wombat]] hole about half a mile (about 800 meters) north of Martin's house. Allen telegraphed the police at [[Strathalbyn, South Australia|Strathalbyn]],Adelaide Observer, 7 June 1862 where the message was received by Police Trooper [[Paul Foelsche]] who reported this by telegraph to headquarters and then rode to Wellington to inform Rollison of the discovery.GRG 5/2/1862/1740, Foelsche’s telegram dated 29 May 1862 Rollison subsequently began a long and very thorough investigation into the murder, and it is largely through his reports to Police Headquarters that so much detail is known about the case.GRG 5/2/1862/1740, enclosure 510 In June 1862, Martin was charged with the murder of Jane Macmanamin. Another man, William Wilsen, who claimed he had been engaged to her, was charged with being an accessory after the fact. Martin was tried and found guilty. He was hanged at the [[Adelaide Gaol]] on 24 December 1862 (Christmas Eve). He is buried between the walls within the gaol. Wilsen was found guilty of assisting Martin after the murder and sentenced to four years hard labour. He was deported to [[Tasmania]] to carry out his sentence. ==Other possible murders== As well as the two murders which were attributed to Martin, there was also suspicion as to the disappearances of two men from the Salt Creek area in 1859. A traveller found a damaged rosewood jeweller's box approximately two and half miles from Salt Creek. On inspection, it contained a piece of linen with the name “G. F. King” written on one of the corners. It was suggested by Edward Bright, a contemporary diarist that a man named Harry Kirby and a jeweller stayed at the ''Traveller’s Rest'' and subsequently disappeared. The police also investigated reports from local Ngarrindjeri that Martin had murdered an indigenous teenager with whom he had had an altercation. Sometime after the boy's suspicious disappearance, a group of indigenous people were bathing in a deep water hole near Salt Creek. They found the boy's body in a bag, weighted down by a large stone. This incident occurred sometime in late 1859 or early 1860, but the police were unable to find any witnesses who would admit to having actually seen the body, only people who claimed to have heard the story from others. ==References== {{Reflist}} * Doolette, Peter (1997) ''Murder, Mishap & Misfortune: A select history of the Coorong'' Coorong Publications {{ISBN|0 646 33895 1}} ==External links== * [http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article50163728 "Execution of Malachi Martin for the Murder at Salt Creek", ''South Adelaide Register'', 26 December 1862] {{DEFAULTSORT:Martin, Malachi (Australian Murderer}} [[Category:People executed for murder]] [[Category:People executed by Australian Colonies by hanging]] [[Category:People executed by South Australia]] [[Category:Executed Australian people]] [[Category:Australian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:1831 births]] [[Category:1862 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century executions by Australia]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by South Australia]] [[Category:Australian serial killers]] [[Category:People from Willunga, South Australia]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:1860s murders in Australia]]

[[Maitland Gaol]] (1996-1997) }} '''Ivan Robert Marko Milat''' (27 December 1944 – 27 October 2019{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Malcolm|last2=Feneley|first2=Rick|title=Life never a picnic for the dirt-poor, troubled Milat clan|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/life-never-a-picnic-for-the-dirtpoor-troubled-milat-clan-20101123-185r8.html|accessdate=1 April 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=24 November 2010}}) was an Australian serial killer who was convicted of the [[backpacker murders]] in 1996. ==Early life== Ivan Milat was the son of a [[Croats|Croatian]] emigrant and labourer, Stjepan Marko "Steven" Milat (1902–1983), and an Australian, Margaret Elizabeth Piddleston (1920–2001), who married when she was 16.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Malcolm|last2=Feneley|first2=Rick|title=Life never a picnic for the dirt-poor, troubled Milat clan|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/life-never-a-picnic-for-the-dirtpoor-troubled-milat-clan-20101123-185r8.html|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=24 November 2010}}{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Les|title=Does crime run in the Milat family tree?|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/does-crime-run-in-the-milat-family-tree-20101127-18bg2.html|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=28 November 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heavenaddress.com/restingplace/margaret-elizabeth-milat/278434|title=Margaret Elizabeth Milat – HeavenAddress Resting Place|website=www.heavenaddress.com|accessdate=21 August 2017}} Milat was the fifth-born of their 14 children,{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Les|title=Milat case stalked by uncertainty|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/stalked-by-uncertainty/2005/07/20/1121539033488.html|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=21 July 2005}} and the growing family first lived in [[Bossley Park]] before relocating to [[Liverpool, New South Wales|Liverpool]]. Many of the 10 Milat boys were well known to local police, and Milat displayed antisocial behaviour at a young age, leading to a stint in a residential school at age 13.{{cite web|url=https://casefilepodcast.com/case-109-belanglo-part-3/|title=Case 109: Belanglo (Part 3)|date=6 April 2019|publisher=}} By 17, he was in a juvenile detention centre for theft, and at 19, was involved in a shop break in. In 1964, he was sentenced to 18 months for a break and enter, and a month after release, he was arrested for driving a stolen car and was sentenced to 2 years hard labour. In September 1967, aged 23, he was sentenced to 3 years for theft. In April 1971, he was charged with the abduction of two 18 year-old hitchhikers and the rape of one of them.{{cite web|title=Ivan Milat Biography|url=http://www.biography.com/people/ivan-milat-17169710|work=[[The Biography Channel]]|publisher=A+E Television Networks, LLC.|accessdate=10 January 2014}} While awaiting trial, he was involved in a string of robberies with some of his brothers, before faking his suicide and fleeing to New Zealand for a year. He was rearrested in 1974, but the robbery and kidnap cases against him failed at trial with the help of the Milat's family lawyer, [[John Marsden (lawyer)|John Marsden]]. He took on a job as a truck driver in 1975, and by the time of the [[Belanglo State Forest]] crimes, Milat had worked on and off for 20 years for the [[Roads & Traffic Authority]] all over the state. ==Backpacker murders== {{main|Backpacker murders}} ===Background=== By the time of the first Belanglo State Forest discoveries, several backpackers had been reported missing. One case involved a young [[Victoria (Australia)|Victorian]] couple from [[Frankston, Victoria|Frankston]], Deborah Everist (19) and James Gibson (19), who had been missing since leaving Sydney for [[ConFest]], near Albury, on 30 December 1989.{{Cite web|url=https://casefilepodcast.com/case-109-belanglo-part-1/|title=Case 109: Belanglo (Part 1)|date=2019-03-23|website=Casefile: True Crime Podcast|language=en-US|access-date=2019-03-31}} Another related to Simone Schmidl (21), from Germany, who had been missing since leaving Sydney for Melbourne on 20 January 1991. Similarly, a German couple, Gabor Neugebauer (21) and Anja Habschied (20), had disappeared after leaving a [[Kings Cross, New South Wales|Kings Cross]] hostel for Mildura on 26 December 1991. Another involved missing British backpackers Caroline Clarke (21) and Joanne Walters (22), who were last seen in Kings Cross on 18 April 1992.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/friends-born-of-sorrow/2006/04/23/1145730809381.html'?page=fullpage|title=Friends born of sorrow|last=Meacham|first=Steve|date=24 April 2006|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=13 January 2014}} === Discovery of victims === [[File:Belanglo_State_Forest_sign.jpg|right|thumb|A sign at the entrance to the Belanglo State Forest]] On 19 September 1992, two runners discovered a concealed corpse while [[orienteering]] in Belanglo.{{cite news|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/twenty-five-years-ago-the-first-victims-of-backpacker-killer-ivan-milat-were-found-in-belanglo-forest-twenty-five-years-ago-the-first-victims-of-backpacker-killer-ivan-milat-were-found-in-belanglo-forest/news-story/f4a31abad223faa68d8d73ca054d297e|title=Twenty five years ago the first victims of Backpacker Killer Ivan Milat were found in Belanglo Forest|last1=Lennon|first1=Troy|date=19 September 2017|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} The following morning, police discovered a second body {{convert|30|m|ft}} from the first.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=acfCYGPaqCoC&pg=PT322|title=Sins of the Brother: The Definitive Story of Ivan Milat and the Backpacker Murders|last1=Whittaker|first1=Mark|last2=Kennedy|first2=Les|date=10 November 2007|publisher=Pan Macmillan Australia|isbn=978-0-330-36284-9|pages=267–268, 322|accessdate=13 January 2014}} Police quickly confirmed, via dental records, that the bodies were those of Clarke and Walters. A search of the area failed to uncover any of the other missing backpackers. In October 1993, however, a local man searching for firewood discovered bones in a particularly remote section of the forest.{{cite book|title=Bombs, Guns and Knives: Violent Crime in Australia|last=Brown|first=Malcolm|publisher=New Holland|year=2000|isbn=1-86436-668-0|location=Sydney|pages=148–153}} He returned with police to the scene where two bodies were quickly discovered and later identified as Gibson and Everist. The presence of Gibson's body in Belanglo puzzled investigators as his camera and backpack had previously been discovered at [[Galston Gorge]], over {{convert|120|km}} to the north. On 1 November 1993, a skeleton was found in a clearing along a fire trail in the forest during a police sweep.{{cite web|url=http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/crime-files/ivan-milat/timeline.html|title=Timeline|work=[[Crime & Investigation Network]]|publisher=AETN UK|accessdate=13 January 2014}} It was later identified as that of Schmidl. Clothing found at the scene was not Schmidl's, but matched that of another missing backpacker, Habschied. On 4 November 1993, the bodies of Habschied and Neugebauer were then found on a nearby fire trail in shallow graves {{convert|50|m}} apart.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/archive/news/the-nine-bodies-found-in-belanglo-forest/story-e6frg6o6-1225958668442|title=The nine bodies found in Belanglo forest|date=22 November 2010|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=13 January 2014|agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]]}} === Search for a serial killer === Examination of the remains showed evidence that some of the victims had been tortured and did not die instantly from their injuries.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-48346543|title=The 'backpacker killer' and unanswered questions|last=Nunn|first=Gary|date=27 October 2019|via=www.bbc.com|accessdate=27 October 2019}} In response, on 14 October 1993, Task Force Air, containing more than 20 detectives and analysts, was set up by the [[New South Wales Police Force|NSW Police]].{{cite web|url=https://casefilepodcast.com/case-109-belanglo-part-2/|title=Case 109: Belanglo (Part 2) cebo|date=30 March 2019|website=Casefile: True Crime Podcast}} On 5 November 1993, the NSW government increased the reward in relation to the killings to $500,000. After developing their [[Offender profiling|profile]] of the killer, the police faced an enormous volume of data from numerous sources.{{cite web|url=http://www.aic.gov.au/media_library/conferences/outlook4/mouzos.pdf|title=Investigating Homicide: New Responses for an Old Crime|last=Mouzos|first=Jenny|work=[[Australian Institute of Criminology]]|publisher=Australian Government|page=5|format=PDF|accessdate=13 January 2014}} Investigators applied [[link analysis]] technology, and as a result, the list of suspects was narrowed from a short list of 230 to an even shorter list of 32.{{cite book|title=Machine Learning Forensics for Law Enforcement, Security, and Intelligence|last=Mena|first=Jesús|publisher=CRC Press (Taylor & Francis Group)|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4398-6069-4|location=Boca Raton, FL}} Speculation arose that the crimes were the work of several killers,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dDOW75aJMR8C&pg=PA313|title=Encyclopedia of Murder and Violent Crime|last=Hickey|first=Eric W.|date=22 July 2003|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-0-7619-2437-1|page=313|accessdate=14 January 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/did-australias-backpacker-killer-have-an-accomplice-2198469.html|title=Did Australia's backpacker killer have an accomplice?|last=Maynard|first=Roger|date=30 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=13 January 2014}} given that most of the victims had been attacked while as pairs, had been killed in different ways, and buried separately. On 13 November 1993, police received a call from Paul Onions (24) in the U.K. On 25 January 1990, Onions had been backpacking in Australia and, while hitchhiking from [[Liverpool railway station, Sydney|Liverpool station]] towards [[Mildura]], had accepted a ride south out of [[Casula, New South Wales|Casula]] from a man known only as "Bill".{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/belanglo-state-forest-once-again-the-home-of-nightmarish-murder/news-story/16f26fd7b5a8d83d658b15059a780435|title=Belanglo State Forest once again the home of nightmarish murder|last1=Starick|first1=Paul|date=22 October 2015|work=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]|accessdate=26 January 2018}}{{cite book|last=Newton|first=Michael|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DwNVbOcTncwC&pg=PA178|title=The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers|date=1 January 2006|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6987-3|pages=178–179|accessdate=13 January 2014}} South of the town of [[Mittagong]], and less than 1 km from Belanglo State Forest, Bill stopped and pulled out a revolver and some ropes stating it was a robbery, at which point Onions managed to flee.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/true-crime-scene/backpacker-murders-how-backpacker-paul-onions-survived-a-close-encounter-with-evil-ivan-milat/news-story/440554edab618a9bcf8ea0de17c3a21b|title=Backpacker murders: How backpacker Paul Onions survived a close encounter with evil Ivan Milat|date=15 May 2015|work=Herald Sun|accessdate=26 January 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/tv-reviews/born-to-kill--ivan-milat/2006/07/25/1153746844314.html|title=Born to Kill – Ivan Milat|last=Oliver|first=Robin|date=26 July 2006|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=11 January 2014}} Onions flagged down a passing motorist, and together they described the assailant and his vehicle to the [[Bowral]] police.{{cite news|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/national/backpacker-who-escaped-ivan-milat-to-return-to-australia/story-e6freooo-1225825004932|title=Backpacker who escaped Ivan Milat to return to Australia|last=Murray|first=David|date=31 January 2010|newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]]|accessdate=13 January 2014}} On 13 April 1994, detectives re-found the note regarding Onions' call. Onions' statement was corroborated by Berry, along with the girlfriend of a man who worked with Milat.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/on-the-trail-of-a--serial-killer-20140413-36m7u.html|title=On the trail of a ... serial killer|last1=Small|first1=Clive|date=19 April 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=26 January 2018}} ===Arrest and trial=== On 26 February 1994, police surveillance of the Milat house at Cinnabar Street, {{NSWcity|Eagle Vale}} commenced. Police learnt that Milat had recently sold his silver [[Nissan Patrol]] four-wheel drive shortly after the discovery of the bodies of Clarke and Walters.{{cite book|last=Marriott|first=Trevor|title=The Evil Within – A Top Murder Squad Detective Reveals The Chilling True Stories of The World's Most Notorious Killers|url=https://archive.org/details/evilwithintopmur0000marr|url-access=registration|accessdate=10 January 2014|date=4 September 2013|publisher=John Blake Publishing|isbn=978-1-78219-365-4|page=[https://archive.org/details/evilwithintopmur0000marr/page/21 21]}} Police also confirmed that Milat had not been working on any of the days of the attacks and acquaintances also told police about Milat's obsession with weapons.{{cite news|last1=Lennon|first1=Troy|title=Twenty five years ago the first victims of Backpacker Killer Ivan Milat were found in Belanglo Forest|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/twenty-five-years-ago-the-first-victims-of-backpacker-killer-ivan-milat-were-found-in-belanglo-forest-twenty-five-years-ago-the-first-victims-of-backpacker-killer-ivan-milat-were-found-in-belanglo-forest/news-story/f4a31abad223faa68d8d73ca054d297e|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=19 September 2017}}{{cite book|last=Chapman|first=Simon|title=Over Our Dead Bodies: Port Arthur and Australia's Fight for Gun Control|url=http://ses.library.usyd.edu.au/bitstream/2123/8938/1/Over-our-dead-bodies_Chapman.pdf|accessdate=10 January 2014|year=2013|publisher=Sydney University Press|isbn=978-1-74332-031-0|page=163}} When the connection between the Belanglo murders and Onions' experience was made, Onions flew to Australia to help with the investigation.{{cite news|last1=Small|first1=Clive|title=On the trail of a ... serial killer|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/on-the-trail-of-a--serial-killer-20140413-36m7u.html|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=19 April 2014}} On 5 May 1994, Onions positively identified Milat as the man who had picked him up and attempted to assault him.{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Malcolm|title=Bombs, Guns and Knives: Violent Crime in Australia|year=2000|publisher=New Holland|location=Sydney|isbn=1-86436-668-0|pages=148–153}} Milat was arrested at his home on 22 May 1994 on robbery and weapon charges related to the Onions attack after 50 police officers surrounded the house.{{cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/milat/discovery_1.html |title=Ivan Milat: The Last Ride|last=Bellamy |first=Patrick|work=[[TruTV]]|publisher=Time Warner Inc.|pages=12–13|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110091143/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/milat/discovery_1.html|archivedate=10 January 2014 |url-status=dead|accessdate=10 January 2014}}{{cite web|title=Timeline|url=http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/crime-files/ivan-milat/timeline.html|work=[[Crime & Investigation Network]]|publisher=AETN UK|accessdate=13 January 2014}} The search of Milat's home revealed various weapons, including a [[.22 LR|.22-calibre]] [[J. G. Anschütz|Anschütz Model 1441/42]] rifle and parts of a .22 calibre [[Ruger 10/22]] rifle that matched the type used in the murders, a [[Browning Arms Company|Browning pistol]], and a [[Bowie knife]].{{Cite web|url=https://casefilepodcast.com/case-109-belanglo-part-4/|title=Case 109: Belanglo (Part 4)|date=2019-04-13|website=Casefile: True Crime Podcast|language=en-US|access-date=2019-06-10}} Also uncovered were items belonging to several of his victims.{{cite web|title=Ivan Milat |url=http://www.citv.com.au/crime-profiles/44/ivan-milat/3/the-crime |work=Crime & Investigation Network |publisher=Foxtel |accessdate=10 January 2014 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110092804/http://www.citv.com.au/crime-profiles/44/ivan-milat/3/the-crime |archivedate=10 January 2014 |df=dmy }} Homes belonging to his mother and five of his brothers were also searched,{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nVJD6V0XAtwC&pg=PT344|title=Australia's Serial Killers|last=Kidd|first=Paul B.|date=1 August 2011|publisher=Pan Macmillan Australia|isbn=978-1-74262-798-4|page=344|accessdate=13 January 2014}} uncovering several more items belonging to the victims. Milat appeared in court on 23 May, but he did not enter a [[plea]].{{cite news|last=Spielman|first=Peter James|title=Suspect charged in seven murders|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1734&dat=19940531&id=MOAhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1VIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6928,2645168|accessdate=13 January 2014|newspaper=[[The Dispatch (Lexington)|The Dispatch]]|date=31 May 1994|agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]}} On 31 May, Milat was also charged with the seven backpacker murders. On 28 June, Milat sacked his defence lawyer, Marsden, and sought legal aid to pay for his defence. Meanwhile, brothers Richard and Walter were tried in relation to weapons, drugs and stolen items found on their properties. A [[Committal procedure|committal hearing]] for Milat regarding the murders began on 24 October and lasted until 12 December, during which over 200 witnesses appeared. Based on the evidence, at the beginning of February 1995, Milat was remanded in custody until June that same year. On 26 March 1996, the trial opened at the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales]] and was prosecuted by [[Mark Tedeschi]].{{cite web|title=The Trial|url=http://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/crime-files/ivan-milat/trial.html|work=Crime & Investigation Network|publisher=AETN UK|accessdate=13 January 2014}} His defence argued that, in spite of the evidence, there was no non-circumstantial proof Milat was guilty and attempted to shift the blame to other members of his family, particularly Richard. 145 witnesses took the stand, including members of the Milat family who endeavoured to provide alibis, and, on 18 June, Milat himself.{{Cite web|url=https://casefilepodcast.com/case-109-belanglo-part-5/|title=Case 109: Belanglo (Part 5)|date=2019-04-20|website=Casefile: True Crime Podcast|language=en-US|access-date=2019-06-10}} On 27 July 1996, after 18 weeks of testimony, a jury found Milat guilty of the murders.{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Frank|title=Milat's brother claims police still treating him as murder suspect|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/22/1085176039666.html?from=storylhs|accessdate=11 January 2014|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=23 May 2004}} He was given a [[life imprisonment|life sentence]] on each count without the possibility of parole. He was also convicted of the attempted murder, false imprisonment and robbery of Onions, for which he received six years [[jail]] each.{{cite book|last=Newton|first=Michael|title=The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DwNVbOcTncwC&pg=PA178|accessdate=13 January 2014|date=1 January 2006|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-0-8160-6987-3|pages=178–179}} == Incarceration and appeals == On his first day, when arriving at [[Maitland Gaol]], Milat was beaten by another inmate.{{cite news|title=Skeleton key to unlock Ivan Milat mystery?|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/skeleton-key-to-unlock-ivan-milat-mystery/story-e6frf7jo-1225912001007|accessdate=10 January 2014|newspaper=[[Herald Sun]]|date=30 August 2010|agency=AAP}} Almost a year later, on 16 May 1997, he made an escape attempt alongside convicted drug dealer and former Sydney councillor George Savvas.{{cite news|title=Maitland Correctional Centre Escape Attempt |url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/V3Key/LA19970520013 |accessdate=10 January 2014 |newspaper=[[Parliament of New South Wales]] |date=20 May 1997 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140110094731/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/V3Key/LA19970520013 |archivedate=10 January 2014 |df=dmy }} The plan failed and Savvas was found hanged in his cell the next day, and Milat was transferred to the maximum security section at [[Goulburn Correctional Centre]] in [[Goulburn, New South Wales]].{{cite news|title=Skeleton key to unlock Ivan Milat mystery?|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/skeleton-key-to-unlock-ivan-milat-mystery/news-story/bb675c84c1205e881219048b5b479bf7|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=Herald Sun|agency=AAP|date=30 August 2010}} In November 1997, Milat appealed against his convictions due to a breach of his common law right to legal representation, as established in ''[[Dietrich v The Queen]]''. However, the [[New South Wales Court of Criminal Appeal]] dismissed the appeal.{{cite AustLII|NSWSC|795|1998|litigants=Regina v Milat |date=26 February 1998}}. In 2004, Milat filed an application with the [[High Court of Australia]] that he be allowed special leave to appeal on new grounds. The application for leave was ultimately dismissed, affirming the Court of Criminal Appeal's decision to disallow his initial appeal.{{Cite AustLII|HCA|17|2004|litigants=Milat v The Queen |parallelcite=(2004) 205 [[Australian Law Reports|ALR]] 338; (2004) 78 [[Australian Law Journal Reports|ALJR]] |date=24 February 2004}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/28/1085641690085.html|title=Serial killer Milat loses conviction appeal|agency=AAP|date=28 May 2004|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=20 May 2017}} On 27 October 2005, in the NSW Supreme Court{{Cite AustLII|NSWSC|920|2005|litigants=R v Milat (backpacker murders)|date=27 October 2005}}. Milat's final avenue of appeal was refused.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/4415216.stm|title=Serial killer's appeal is refused|date=7 November 2005|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2 June 2015}} In 2006, two other application attempts were rejected as well, as was one in November 2011. In 2001, following the opening of the High Risk Management Corrections Centre (Supermax) at Goulburn Correctional Centre, Milat was transferred from the maximum security section of the prison into one of its 45 new units.{{Cite news|title=Australia’s worst serial killer Ivan Milat has died aged 74|url=https://www.news.com.au/national/australias-worst-serial-killer-ivan-milat-has-died-aged-74/news-story/c0ec9be649b146fc3919ce05387b475d|accessdate=29 October 2019|work=[[News.com.au]]|date=27 October 2019}} In 2006, a toaster and TV given to Milat in his cell caused a public outcry.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/milat-gets-tv-toaster-returned-to-cell-20060715-gdnyv3.html|title=Milat gets TV, toaster returned to cell|date=2006-07-14|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2019-06-10}} == Health and death == On 26 January 2009, Milat cut off his little finger with a plastic knife, with the intention of mailing it to the [[High Court of Australia]] to force an appeal.{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/medics-unable-to-reattach-milats-finger-20090127-7qg5.html|title=Medics unable to reattach Milat's finger|date=27 January 2009|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=27 January 2009|agency=AAP}} He was taken to [[Goulburn Base Hospital]] under high security; however, on 27 January 2009 Milat was returned to prison after doctors decided surgery was not possible.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/news/milat-lops-finger-back-in-jail/story-fna7dq6e-1111118675241|title=Serial killer Ivan Milat cuts off finger in High Court protest|date=27 January 2009|newspaper=[[News.com.au]]|accessdate=10 January 2014}} Milat had previously self-harmed in 2001, when he swallowed razor blades, staples and other metal objects. In May 2011, Milat went on a 9-day hunger strike, losing 25 kilograms in an unsuccessful attempt to be given a [[PlayStation]].{{cite news|last=Bashan|first=Yoni|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/ivan-milat-on-hunger-strike-over-playstation/story-e6frfkvr-1226056097963|title=Ivan Milat on hunger strike over Playstation|date=15 May 2011|work=News.com.au|accessdate=17 May 2011}} In May 2019, Milat was transferred to the [[Prince of Wales Hospital (Sydney)|Prince of Wales Hospital]], {{NSWcity|Randwick}}, and was subsequently diagnosed with terminal [[oesophageal cancer]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/serial-killer-ivan-milat-unlikely-to-return-to-supermax-after-terminal-cancer-diagnosis-20190516-p51nu5.html|title=Serial killer Ivan Milat unlikely to return to supermax after terminal cancer diagnosis|last=Cormack|first=Lucy|date=15 May 2019|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=16 May 2019}} Following his treatment he was transferred to the [[Long Bay Correctional Centre]] to continue his custodial sentences.{{Cite news|url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/ivan-milat-moves-to-long-bay-jail-hospital-from-prince-of-wales-20190521-p51pjl.html|title=Ivan Milat moves to Long Bay jail hospital from Prince of Wales|date=28 May 2019|access-date=5 Jul 2019}} On 9 August 2019, a terminally ill Milat was moved to a secure treatment unit located at the [[Prince of Wales Hospital (Sydney)|Prince of Wales Hospital]] following the loss of 20 kilograms in previous weeks; Milat was also exhibiting a high temperature. His status, however, was reported as not life-threatening.{{Cite news|title=Serial killer Ivan Milat transferred to Sydney hospital from jail|url=https://www.news.com.au/national/nsw-act/news/serial-killer-ivan-milat-transferred-to-sydney-hospital-from-jail/news-story/aacc98d5c80e09ff74e064377939960b|accessdate=9 August 2019|work=[[The 7.30 Report]]|date=9 August 2019}} On 27 October 2019, Milat died from oesophagus and stomach cancer at 4:07 a.m. within the hospital wing at Long Bay Correctional Centre. He was 74 years old.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/rot-in-hell-australia-s-most-notorious-serial-killer-ivan-milat-74-dies|title='Rot in hell': Australia’s most notorious serial killer Ivan Milat, 74, dies|website=SBS News|language=en|access-date=2020-01-03}} Prior to his death, Milat wrote a letter to his family requesting that his funeral be paid for by the New South Wales Government. The request was denied by NSW Corrections Minister Anthony Roberts. Instead, Milat's body was cremated with the full reimbursement of costs to be paid from his prison account.{{Cite web|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-11-10/ivan-milat-forced-to-pay-for-his-own-cremation/11690598|title=Ivan Milat's dying request refused|date=2019-11-10|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2020-01-03}} == Other developments == On 8 November 2004, Milat gave a televised interview on ''[[Australian Story]]'', in which he denied that any of his family had been implicated in the seven murders.{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=John|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2004-11-08/milat-says-brothers-innocent/581290|title=Milat says brothers innocent|date=8 November 2004|work=ABC News|accessdate=2 June 2015}} A miniseries on the [[Seven Network]], ''[[Catching Milat]]'', screened in 2015 and focused on the members of "Task Force Air" who tracked Milat.{{cite news|last1=Blundell|first1=Graeme|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/review/catching-milat-revisits-backpacker-murders/news-story/bf63c8648451fb0bf2f8118fcd2db555|title=Catching Milat revisits backpacker murders|date=16 May 2005|work=The Australian|accessdate=9 January 2017}} A book by Milat's nephew, Alistair Shipsey, ''The Milat Letters'' ({{ISBN|1785547844}}) was released in 2016;{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Milat-Letters-Alistair-Shipsey/dp/1785547844|title=The Milat Letters|website=www.amazon.com|access-date=2019-03-31}}{{Cite news|last=Murray|first=David|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/nation/serial-killer-milat-in-advance-stages-of-cancer/news-story/af9201d3736940d9085e55f1184e9caa|title=Serial killer Milat ‘has little chance of survival’|date=16 May 2019|work=The Australian|access-date=16 May 2019|last2=Cortis}} In December 2018, Australian author [[Amanda Howard]] was writing a book on his crimes, based on her correspondence with Milat.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/ivan-milat-letters-20190517-p51ok3.html|title='He’s very confident of going to heaven': the letters of Ivan Milat|last=Begley|first=Lucy Cormack, Patrick|date=2019-05-18|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2019-06-26}} In 2012, Milat's great-nephew Matthew Milat and his friend Cohen Klein (both aged 19 at the time of their sentencing) were sentenced to 43 years and 32 years in prison, respectively, for murdering David Auchterlonie on his 17th birthday with an axe at the Belanglo State Forest in November 2010. Matthew Milat struck Auchterlonie with the double-headed axe as Klein audio-recorded the attack with a mobile phone.{{cite news|last=Wells|first=Jamelle|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-06-08/milat-relative-gets-30-years-for-axe-murder/4060442|title=Milat relative gets 30 years for axe murder|date=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|accessdate=10 January 2014}}{{cite news|last=Dale|first=Amy|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/matthew-milat-sentenced-to-43-years/story-e6frfkvr-1226388884080|title=Matthew Milat sentenced to 30 years jail for 'cold blooded' murder|date=8 June 2012|newspaper=News.com.au|accessdate=10 January 2014}} In May 2015, Milat's brother Boris Milat told Steve Aperen, a former homicide detective who serves as a consultant with the [[Los Angeles Police Department]] and the U.S. [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], that Milat was responsible for another shooting: that of taxi cab driver Neville Knight, in 1962 after Milat admitted to the crime. After conducting [[polygraph]] tests with Boris Milat and Allan Dillon, the man convicted of Knight's shooting, Aperen is convinced that Milat did in fact shoot Knight.{{cite news|last1=Lees|first1=Philippa|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/sunday-night/features/a/27411151/detective-says-no-doubt-over-ivan-milat-claim/|title=Detective Says 'No Doubt' Over Ivan Milat Claim|date=3 May 2015|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|accessdate=2 June 2015}} ==Personal life== In 1975, Milat met a 16-year-old girl who was pregnant by his cousin. They married in 1983, making him stepfather to her son, and they had one daughter of their own.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/subscribe/news/1/?sourceCode=DTWEB_WRE170_a&dest=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailytelegraph.com.au%2Fnews%2Fnsw%2Fivan-milats-daughter-lynise-opens-up-on-serial-killers-death%2Fnews-story%2F3e70be6273440c17f89ac809b02136cb&memtype=anonymous&mode=premium&nk=15c89cd59c57698848bd5786d8066292-1582844345|title=Dailytelegraph.com.au {{!}} Subscribe to The Daily Telegraph for exclusive stories|website=www.dailytelegraph.com.au|access-date=2020-02-27}}{{Cite book|last=Kennedy|first=Les|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=acfCYGPaqCoC&pg=PT152&lpg=PT152&dq=karen+duck+jason+milat&source=bl&ots=FDTaZo9dpu&sig=ACfU3U2406H5mncOA-kQq5tMqGwYpd4AiQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwibxOnFgMflAhULXn0KHcz3D8IQ6AEwFXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=karen%20duck%20jason%20milat&f=false|title=Sins of the Brother|last2=Whittaker|first2=Mark|date=2007-11-10|publisher=Pan Macmillan Australia|isbn=978-1-74262-404-4|language=en}} However, she left him in 1987 due to [[domestic violence]] and they divorced in October 1989. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Milat, Ivan}} [[Category:Australian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Australian people of Croatian descent]] [[Category:Australian prisoners sentenced to multiple life sentences]] [[Category:Australian rapists]] [[Category:Australian serial killers]] [[Category:Criminals from Sydney]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by New South Wales]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by New South Wales]] [[Category:20th-century Australian criminals]] [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:2019 deaths]]

{{more citations needed|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Martha Marek | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = Martha Löwenstein | alias = | birth_date = 1904 | birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1938|12|06|1904}} | death_place = Vienna, Austria | cause = [[Guillotined]] | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = [[Death]] | victims = 4 | beginyear = 1932 | endyear = 1937 | country = [[Austria]] | states = | apprehended = 1938 | imprisoned = }} '''Martha Marek''' (''née'' '''Löwenstein'''; 1904 – December 6, 1938) was an [[Austria]]n [[serial killer]] who caused media attention during the interwar period.
== Insurance fraud == Martha Löwenstein inherited a villa in the Vienna Woods and financial means in August 1923 from her 50-year-old patron as sole heir, months later she married the student Emil Marek. Within two years, the money was used up by the couple.
In 1925 Martha and her husband Emil first entered the mass media coverage: Emil had lost his leg while chopping wood on June 25, 1925, a day after Martha had put an insurance policy on him.<ref>Nettersheim, Christoph, ''Schrecklich nette Frauen''.</ref> As the circumstances were very strange to the insurance company, they refused to pay the sum and a lawsuit began. In the course of which, forensics experts were able to clearly prove by multiple traces on the leg that it was self-mutilation. Emil Marek, who was almost fully obedient to his wife, had purposely injured himself to get the sum insured.
The public, however, was largely on the beautiful Marek's side and suspected that the insurance company wanted to suppress the payment through legal mishaps. Marek and her husband were acquitted of fraud in 1927 and sentenced to only a small prison sentence, as Martha had tried to bribe or slander the coroners. The insurance company agreed to settle the matters out of court and paid a large sum of money.
== Prison == Martha Marek spent the short prison time in a cell with the poisoner [[Leopoldine Lichtenstein]], who in 1925 had poisoned her husband with the [[thallium]]-containing rat paste "Zelio".<ref>{{cite journal |title=Thallium-Vergiftung (Selbstmordversuch mit Zeliopaste) |trans-title=Thallium poisoning (suicide attempt with Zeliopaste) |last=Heinichen |first=W. |date=December 1931 |journal=[[Archives of Toxicology|Sammlung von Vergiftungsfällen]] |language=de |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=27–28 |doi=10.1007/BF02460485}}</ref> This allegedly inspired Martha to do her other deeds. After the media popularity had subsided, the sum had been used up and Emil's entrepreneurial plans as an inventor had failed, the Mareks experienced economic hardship.
== Murders == After Emil Marek, who had always been sickly after the leg amputation, died unexpectedly on July 31, 1932, public attention returned to the widow. When her two children developed similar symptoms and their daughter died shortly after, Martha was able to play off the role of a long-suffering widow and mother, and she was given a broad wave of compassion, including financial donations. An aunt of hers, Susanne Löwenstein, even went so far as to appoint her as her sole heir, and promptly died thereafter in 1934.
After Marek had used up the inheritance, she found in tailor Felicitas Kittenberger another victim. Kittenberger was taken in by Marek as a subtenant and was persuaded to take a life insurance in Martha's favour. Kittenberger died shortly after, which, however, aroused the suspicion of her son, who filed charges. The subsequent investigation and exhumation of the bodies revealed that Marek had murdered all four victims with the toxic Zelio paste, which was then freely available.
== Conviction == Back in court, Martha Marek faked seizures and blindness, and had to be carried to the courtroom in a specially-constructed chair. She was [[sentenced to death]] on May 19, 1938 by the jury, with the court assuming that Marek, as a woman, following the Austrian tradition, would be pardoned by the [[President of Austria|Federal President]] for [[life imprisonment]]. In the meantime, however, Austria had been attached to the [[German Reich]] and [[Adolf Hitler]] rejected the petition for clemency. Marek was executed on December 6, 1938, as the first delinquent on the recently brought from [[Berlin]] to Vienna guillotine, in the Vienna Regional Court by the executioner [[Johann Reichhart]].
== Literature ==
* Harald Seyrl: ''Tatort Wien.'' Band 2: ''Die Zeit von 1925–1944.'' Scharnstein, Wien 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-90169-709-8}}. * Hans-Dieter Otto: ''Lexikon der ungesühnten Morde. Unaufgeklärte Fälle, Unentdeckte Verbrechen, Umstrittene Freisprüche'' p. 129 ff, F.A. Herbig, München 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-7766-2533-2}}. * Helga Schimmer: ''Mord in Wien. Wahre Kriminalfälle.'' Haymon-Verlag, Innsbruck 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-85218-876-8}}. pp. 61–69. * Christoph Nettersheim: ''Schrecklich nette Frauen'', Bucher, München 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-7658-1883-7}}, pp. 10–16

{{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Gennady Modestovich Mikhasevich | image = GennadyMikhasevich.png | caption = | birthname = | alias = | birth_date = 7 April 1947 | birth_place = [[Vitebsk Oblast]], [[Byelorussian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = 25 September 1987 (aged 40) | death_place = | cause =[[Execution by firing squad]] | conviction = [[Murder]] | victims = 33 confirmed
43 confessed
55+ estimated | country = [[Byelorussian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | states = [[Vitebsk Oblast]] | beginyear = 1971 | endyear = 1985 | apprehended = 9 December 1985 | penalty = [[Capital punishment|Death]] }} '''Gennady Modestovich Mikhasevich''' ({{lang-be|Генадзь Мадэставіч Міхасевіч}}; 7 April, 1947 – 25 September, 1987) was a prolific [[Soviet]] [[serial killer]]. He murdered 33{{cite web |url=http://crynews.ru/persprint/553.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-23 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830133946/http://crynews.ru/persprint/553.html |archivedate=2011-08-30 }} women during the period from 1971 to 1985 in [[Vitebsk]], [[Polotsk]] and the rural areas in the nearby regions of the [[Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic|Byelorussian SSR]]. == Biography == Gennady Mikhasevich was born in the village of Ist ([[Vitebsk Oblast]]) in 1947,Newton, Michael (2006). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DwNVbOcTncwC&pg=PA177&dq= ''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'']. Infobase Publishing. p. 177. {{ISBN|0816069875}}. and served in the army. He committed his first murder in May 1971. He himself later explained that the killing spree started after he had returned from the army only to find out that his girlfriend had left him and got married in the meantime. On the night of 14 May, 1971, he was on his way from [[Vitebsk]] to [[Polotsk]]. It was late so he could not catch a bus to Polotsk where his parents lived. Mikhasevich reported that he was feeling despondent because of the breakup with his girlfriend, and had prepared a loop to [[suicide|hang himself]]. By chance, however, he encountered a young woman on the road and, in order to vent his anger, decided to kill her. He murdered again in October 1971, and strangled two other women in 1972, near Vitebsk. Mikhasevich graduated from a technical school in Vitebsk in 1973 and returned to Ist, starting work in a [[sovkhoz]]. He got married in 1976. In the meantime, the murders went on. Many of his murders were committed to facilitate [[rape]]. He invariably strangled or smothered his victims, either assaulting them in solitary locations or, during later years, after having lured them into his own red [[Zaporozhets]] or the machines of his workplace (he later had a job in machine repair service). Mikhasevich did not carry weapons, choosing instead to use a variety of improvised means, including in one case, a cord made of [[rye]]. Besides killing, he robbed his victims of money and valuable items, some of which he would later present to his wife as a gift. He would also take mundane household items, like scissors. In outward appearance, Gennady Mikhasevich was a good family man, a [[teetotaller]] with two children and was a conscientious worker; he was also a member of the [[CPSU|Communist Party]] (also serving as a local party functionary) and of [[Voluntary People's Druzhina]]. The investigation started to advance in the 1980s, as the young investigator Nikolay Ignatovich firmly believed that all the killings of females near motorways in the region were not separate, isolated cases as previous investigators had conveniently believed, but had in fact been committed by one person, a [[serial killer]]. The police also suspected that the serial killer was using a red Zaporozhets; as they started checking all the people of the Oblast who possessed such a car, Mikhasevich, [[Voluntary People's Druzhina|as a druzhinnik]], participated in these actions - essentially, searching for himself. This also gave him insight into the investigation itself, enabling him to learn of the steps investigators were taking beforehand, and allowing Mikhasevich to plan his own steps to avoid them. The year 1985 was especially 'prolific' for the murderer: he killed 12 women in this year alone. Eventually, Mikhasevich, who was now getting concerned, made a fatal mistake. In order to derail the investigation, he sent an anonymous letter to the local newspaper on behalf of an imaginary underground organization, 'Patriots of Vitebsk', purportedly calling on his fellow militants to intensify their struggle of killing communists and lewd women. When he left a similar hand-written note next to his new victim, again signed on behalf of 'Patriots of Vitebsk', the investigators started to ascertain the handwriting of the male residents of the Oblast. Having checked 556,000 samples, the experts detected that the sample with the handwriting of Gennady Modestovich Mikhasevich bore a striking resemblance to the handwriting on the murderer's notes. Further investigation revealed other evidence, convincing them of Mikhasevich's guilt. He was finally arrested in December 1985, after initial denial, he confessed and was sentenced to death and executed by firing squad in 1987. His case became notorious in the USSR (“The Vitebsk Case” (“Витебское дело”)), as it revealed both the incompetence of the police and the corruption of the [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement agencies]]: by the time Mikhasevich was finally arrested, 14 people had already been convicted for the crimes Mikhasevich committed, the suspects had been often forced to confess by torture, and a couple of them had been sentenced to death and executed for crimes they did not commit. == Footnotes == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110830133946/http://crynews.ru/persprint/553.html Biography of Mikhasevich in Russian] * [http://www.serial-killers.ru/karts/mihasevich.htm Biography of Mikhasevich in Russian at serial-killer.ru] * [http://www.serial-killers.ru/foto/mihasevich.htm Photos of Mikhasevich with commentaries in Russian] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mikhasevich, Gennady}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:Soviet serial killers]] [[Category:Executed Soviet people from Belarus]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:People executed by the Soviet Union by firearm]] [[Category:Soviet people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Soviet rapists]] [[Category:Executed Soviet serial killers]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:Belarusian people executed by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:Executed Belarusian people]]

{{short description|Brazilian serial killer}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = José Vicente Matias | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = "Corumbá" | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|09|24}} | birth_place = [[Firminópolis]], [[Goiás]], [[Brazil]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = 23 years imprisonment | victims = 6 | beginyear = 1999 | endyear = 2005 | country = [[Brazil]] | states = [[Minas Gerais]], [[Bahia]], [[Goiás]], [[Maranhão]] | apprehended = March 29, 2005 | imprisoned = }} '''José Vicente Matias''' (born September 24, 1966 in [[Firminópolis]], [[Goiás]]), also known as '''"Corumbá"''', is a [[Brazil]]ian [[serial killer]] and former [[artisan]] who raped, murdered and then dismembered 6 women between 1999 and 2005. In addition to killing, Matias also practised [[cannibalism]] with the remains of his victims, ingesting blood and brain pieces from them.
In his testimonies, 'Corumbá' gave contradictory statements on several occasions. He sometimes mentioned suffering "influences" from the [[Devil]], who whispered in his ear that his mission was to kill seven women, while on other occasions, he cited [[xenophobia]] and jokes aimed at his [[sexual impotence]]. Before this, he had been arrested by the police for rape and violent assault. He was sentenced to 23 years imprisonment on June 2, 2008.
== Victims == * '''Natália Canhas Carneiro''' - the 15-year-old [[Minas Gerais]] native was killed in September 1999 in the municipality of [[Três Marias]].<ref name=Corumba>{{Citeweb|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/cotidiano/ult95u107622.shtml|title=Craftsman says he killed three other women at the behest of the devil|publisher=Online Folha|date=6 April 2005|accessdate=25 January 2011|language=Portuguese}}</ref> * '''Simone Lima Pinho''' - the 26-year-old [[hippie]] and fellow artisan from [[Bahia]] was beaten and stoned to death in June 2000 in the municipality of [[Lençóis]].<ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://www.badaueonline.com.br/2005/12/15/Pagina5044.htm|title='Corumbá' indicates the crime scene in Lençóis in Bahia|publisher=Badauê Online|date=15 December 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011|language=Portuguese|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612212713/http://www.badaueonline.com.br/2005/12/15/Pagina5044.htm|archive-date=12 June 2008|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=Corumba/> * '''Lidiane Vieira de Melo''' - the 16-year-old from [[Goiana]] spent a day and a half bound while Matias drank her blood. After her death, she had her body dismembered. She was killed in [[Goiânia]], in January 2004.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://www.badaueonline.com.br/2005/12/15/Pagina5044.htm|title='Corumbá' sentenced to 23 years for killing student|publisher=Jornal Pequeno|date=4 June 2008|accessdate=25 January 2011|language=Portuguese|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612212713/http://www.badaueonline.com.br/2005/12/15/Pagina5044.htm|archive-date=12 June 2008|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=Corumba/> * '''Katryn Rakitov''' - 29-year-old [[Russia]]n-[[Israel]]i who was killed in [[Pirenópolis]], Goiás.<ref name=Corumba/> * '''Maryanne Kern''' - the 49-year-old [[Germany|German]] tourist was found in a shallow grave in [[Barreirinhas]] municipality, in [[Maranhão]].<ref name=Corumba/> * '''Núria Fernandez Collada''' - the 27-year-old [[Spain|Spanish]] tourist was killed with blows to the head, and had parts of her brain and blood ingested after Matias performed a dance ritual. She was killed on the beach of Itatinga in [[Alcântara, Maranhão]].<ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://elo.com.br/portal/noticias/ver/127836/decretada-prisao-preventiva-do-maniaco-da-praia.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120718220827/http://elo.com.br/portal/noticias/ver/127836/decretada-prisao-preventiva-do-maniaco-da-praia.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=18 July 2012|title=Decree preventative detention of the "Beach Maniac"|publisher=ELO|accessdate=25 January 2011|language=Portuguese}}</ref>

{{Infobox serial killer |name=Michael Wayne McGray |image= |caption= |alt= |birth_name=Michael Wayne McGray |alias= |birth_date={{birth date and age|1965|7|11}} |birth_place=[[Collingwood, Ontario|Collingwood]], [[Ontario]] [[Canada]] |conviction=[[Murder]] |sentence=[[Life imprisonment]] |victims=7–18+ |beginyear=1985 |endyear=1998 |country=[[Canada]], [[United States of America|U.S.]](alleged)}}
'''Michael Wayne McGray''' (born July 11, 1965) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[serial killer|serial killer]] convicted of killing seven individuals, and claims to have killed eleven others, between 1985 and 1998.
==Early life== McGray was born in [[Collingwood, Ontario|Collingwood]], [[Ontario]], but was raised in [[Argyle, Nova Scotia|Argyle]], [[Nova Scotia]].<ref>[http://thechronicleherald.ca/novascotia/37883-mcgray-gets-another-life-term thechronicleherald.ca: "McGray gets another life term"], 30 Nov 2011</ref>
==Crimes== On May 1, 1985, McGray murdered 17-year-old hitchhiker Elizabeth Gale Tucker in a wooded area near [[Weymouth, Nova Scotia]].<ref name=gm/> Gregory George Ashford was interviewed in connection with this murder.<ref>The Ottawa Citizen: "Murder suspect returned to Toronto", 30 Dec 1985</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Cox |first1=Kevin |title=Serial killer pleads guilty in teen's death |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/serial-killer-pleads-guilty-in-teens-death/article4148577/ |website=theglobeandmail.com |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=May 30, 2001|accessdate=July 13, 2019}}</ref>
On November 14, 1987, McGray and two accomplices, Mark Gibbons, and Norm Warren robbed a taxi driver in [[Saint John, New Brunswick|Saint John]], [[New Brunswick]]. After police arrival, Gibbons' dead body was discovered at Market Square. Warren was charged with the murder of Gibbons, however he was found not guilty of murder after a jury trial. McGray received a five-year prison sentence for his role in the robbery, but was not charged in connection with Gibbons' death.<ref name="SKF">{{cite book |last1=Simpson |first1=Paul |title=The Serial Killer Files |date=May 18, 2017 |publisher=Little Brown Book Group |isbn=978-1-47213-673-2 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=949zCwAAQBAJ |accessdate=July 13, 2019}}</ref><ref name=gm/>
In 1991, McGray was still serving time in prison due to his 1987 robbery conviction, however, he was given a three-day weekend pass to stay at a halfway house in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] during Easter weekend. On March 30, 1991, McGray met Robert Assaly in Montreal's Gay Village. Assaly invited McGray back to his apartment where McGray fatally stabbed him in the throat and chest multiple times. On March 31, 1991, McGray returned to the Gay Village and met Gaetan Ethier, who invited McGray back to his apartment. After spending the night at Ethier's apartment, McGray stabbed Ethier to death. McGray did not return to prison after his three-day weekend pass, however, he was re-arrested only a few days later.<ref name="SKF"/>
The [[National Parole Board]] expressed concern in 1995 about McGray's problems with anger and [[substance abuse]], and that McGray disappeared for more than a year while on [[parole]], "which clearly indicated a serious breach of trust and a blatant disregard for conditions of release."<ref name=cp>[http://www.walnet.org/csis/news/halifax_2000/cp-000324.html Canadian Press: "Police looking at unsolved cases for links to McGray's claims"], 24 Mar 2000</ref>
On the morning of February 28, 1998, Joan Hicks and her 11-year-old daughter Nina in [[Moncton, New Brunswick]] were murdered at their apartment. Joan was found lying on the floor of the bathroom in a pool of blood, having been beaten, strangled and her throat cut with serrated knife. Her daughter Nina was found hung in her bedroom closet by a piece of rope after having been choked with a rope.<ref name="SKF"/> McGray was named by a witness as the murderer and he was arrested the next day.<ref name=cbc>[https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/possible-serial-killer-in-custody-in-moncton-1.184325 cbc.ca: "Possible serial killer in custody in Moncton"], 29 Oct 1999</ref>
He later confessed to murders of Robert Assaly and Gaetan Ethier in 1991.<ref name=cbc/>
On March 20, 2000, he pled guilty to the murder of Hicks.<ref name=gm/> McGray claims to have killed 11 other victims across Canada, including [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], Saint John, Montreal, [[Ottawa]], [[Toronto]], [[Calgary]], [[Vancouver]], and the [[Americans|American]] city of [[Seattle]]. He claimed that he would provide information to the authorities on the killings in exchange for specific demands being met.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.crimezzz.net/serialkillers/M/McGRAY_michael_wayne.php |title=crimezzz.net: "serial killers by name – McGRAY Michael Wayne" |access-date=2012-11-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191210121926/http://www.crimezzz.net/serialkillers/M/McGRAY_michael_wayne.php |archive-date=2019-12-10 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name=gm>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/i-got-very-good-at-it-killer-says/article4162061/ G+M: "'I got very good at it,' killer says"], 24 Mar 2000</ref>
In May 2001, McGray was charged with a sixth murder, the 1985 killing of Elizabeth Gail Tucker in Nova Scotia. This charge occurred as a result of several interviews he gave the previous year; as a result of the interviews, police across the country re-opened [[cold case]] files.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/serial-killer-charged-with-nova-scotia-teen-s-murder-1.259729 cbc.ca: "Serial killer charged with Nova Scotia teen's murder"], 23 May 2001</ref> McGray blamed his urge to kill on beatings he received as a child, and warned he would kill again if he did not receive proper treatments.<ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/11/29/prison-couldnt-keep-michael-wayne-mcgray-from-killing-just-like-he-said-it-wouldnt/ nationalpost.com: "Prison couldn’t keep Michael Wayne McGray from killing — just like he said it wouldn’t"], 29 Nov 2011</ref>
In November 2010, following a transfer to the [[Mountain Institution]] medium-security prison in [[Agassiz, British Columbia|Agassiz]], [[British Columbia]], McGray killed his cellmate, 33-year-old Jeremy Phillips. The [[Crown prosecutor]] related that McGray claimed that Phillips invented a false hostage-taking scenario where McGray would tie him up, and Phillips would then be brought to an [[infirmary]]; McGray complied with the plan, and then strangled Phillips. Lawyers of the victim's family doubted the claims, as Phillips was scheduled to be released on parole, while two inmates related that Phillips had requested to not be held in the same block as McGray, but prison officers denied the request. A resulting [[Coroner|coroner's]] inquest recommended that serial killers be housed in single cells. The [[Sainte-Anne-des-Plaines, Quebec|Ste-Anne-des-Plaines Institution]], which was reputed to be the highest-security prison in Canada, housed McGray in 2012.<ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/11/01/dont-make-serial-killers-roomies-in-prison-coroners-jury-recommends/ nationalpost.com: "Don't make serial killers roomies in prison, coroner's jury recommends"], 1 Nov 2012</ref>
On July 12, 2019, the Nova Scotia Supreme Court revealed that McGray was the prime suspect in the 1995 murder of Brenda Way who was found with her neck slashed in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia. Her boyfriend, Glen Assoun had been convicted and spent 17 years in prison for the crime he always denied.<ref>Jackson Weaver (July 12, 2019). [https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/michael-mcgray-serial-killer-brenda-way-glen-assoun-1.5209623 Who is serial killer Michael Wayne McGray?], CBC News online. Accessed July 12, 2019.</ref>
==Timeline of events== The murders included random attacks of strangers and the killing of acquaintances. ;1985 * 1 May 1985 – Murder of Elizabeth Gale Tucker, near Weymouth, Digby County Nova Scotia; she was a hitch hiker. ;1987 * <date> Murder of Mark Daniel Gibbons, an alleged accomplice in a Saint John, New Brunswick; stabbed. ;1991 * 29 March – Given 3-day parole from [[Atlantic Institution]], Renous, New Brunswick. * 31 March – Murder of Robert Assaly; retired school teacher he met at a gay bar in Montreal while on parole; bludgeoned and stabbed. <ref name=G&M/> * 1 April – Murder of Gaetan Ethier; met at a gay bar in Montreal while on parole; stabbed. * Late May – Returned to prison in New Brunswick after eluding police for nearly 2 months. ;1995 * November 12 (alleged) – As of 2019, prime suspect in murder of Brenda Way, Dartmouth Nova Scotia.<ref>Aly Thomson and Blair Rhodes (July 12, 2019). [https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/glen-assoun-wrongful-conviction-records-unsealed-1.5207994 RCMP deleted documents in wrongful conviction case, federal report finds], CBC News online. Accessed July 12, 2019.</ref> ;1998 * 28 February – Murder of Joan Hicks and her 11-year-old daughter Nina in Moncton, New Brunswick; at their home. ;1999 * March – Arrested in Moncton for murder of Joan and Nina Hicks. * Fall – Charged in Montreal killings. ;2000 * January – Charged in Saint John killing. * 20 March – Pleaded guilty to the murder of Joan Hicks; denied murdering her child.<ref name=G&M>Erin Anderssen (April 6, 2000). [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/crown-paints-picture-of-remorseless-killer/article4163275/ Crown paints picture of remorseless killer], ''Globe and Mail'' online. Accessed July 12, 2019.</ref> * 25 April – Sentenced to 20 years for Assaly and Ethier murders.<ref>25 April 2000. [https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/mcgray-pleads-guilty-to-two-more-murders-1.212505 McGray pleads guilty to two more murders]. CBC News. Accessed July 12, 2019. </ref> ;2010 * November – Murder of cellmate Jeremy Phillips at the Mountain Institution in British Columbia.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{short description|Colombian serial killer}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Jaime Iván Martínez | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = Jaime Iván Martínez Betancur | alias = "The Guarne Killer"
"The Monster of the East" | birth_date = 1972 | birth_place = [[Samaná, Caldas]], [[Colombia]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = 42 years imprisonment | victims = 4–20+ | beginyear = 2005 | endyear = 2016 | country = [[Colombia]] | states = [[Antioquia Department|Antioquia]], possibly also [[Valle del Cauca Department|Valle del Cauca]] | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Jaime Iván Martínez Betancur''' (born 1972 in [[Samaná, Caldas|Samaná]], [[Colombia]]), known as the '''Guarne Killer''' and '''The Monster of the East''', is a [[Colombia|Colombian]] [[serial killer]].[https://www.rcnradio.com/colombia/antioquia/condenan-42-anos-prision-al-llamado-asesino-serie-guarne Condenan a 42 años de prisión al llamado "asesino en serie" de Guarne] [[RCN Radio]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.[https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-16624903 Asesino en serie en Guarne guardaba prendas de sus víctimas] [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|''El Tiempo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.[https://www.semana.com/nacion/multimedia/fiscalia-investiga-a-un-asesino-en-serie-en-guarne/478466 El asesino en serie de Guarne] ''[[Semana (Colombia)|Semana]]''. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. He was responsible for the murder of several people, including the killings of his wife and children.Natalio Cosoy (20 de junio de 2016). [https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-36582249 Jaime Iván Martínez Betancur, el colombiano que confesó ser asesino en serie y haber matado al menos a 20 personas] [[BBC]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. The bodies of the victims were exhumed by specialized personnel of the [[Office of the Attorney General of Colombia|Attorney General's Office]], in cooperation with the Technical Investigation Body (CTI), the Unified Action Groups for Personal Liberty (GAULA) and [[Police dog|police dogs]], who conducted on-site investigations as part of the procedures.[http://www.radiosantafe.com/2016/06/20/exhumados-cuerpos-de-dos-menores-victimas-de-jaime-martinez-el-asesino-de-guarne/ Exhumados cuerpos de dos menores víctimas de Jaime Martínez, el asesino de Guarne] [[Radio Santa Fe]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. The Colombian authorities suspect that he has killed between 20 and 25 people for a decade.[https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-16623809 Capturan en Antioquia a asesino en serie que mató a 20 personas] [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|''El Tiempo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.[https://www.elnuevosiglo.com.co/articulos/6-2016-ser%C3%ADan-25-las-v%C3%ADctimas-del-asesino-de-guarne Serían 25 las víctimas del asesino de Guarne] ''[[El Nuevo Siglo]]''. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. He was sentenced to 42 years in prison by a specialized court in the [[Antioquia Department]].[https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/nacional/antioquia/el-asesino-de-guarne-pagara-42-anos-de-prision-articulo-675847 El asesino de Guarne pagará 42 años de prisión] [[El Espectador (periódico)|''El Espectador'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. == Crimes == It is believed that Martínez committed in the span of a decade.[https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-16624903 Asesino en serie en Guarne guardaba prendas de sus víctimas] [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|''El Tiempo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. One of the victims was identified as Natalia García Gil, Martínez's former wife, whom was hanged with the use of nylon.[https://www.rcnradio.com/colombia/antioquia/condenan-42-anos-prision-al-llamado-asesino-serie-guarne Condenan a 42 años de prisión al llamado "asesino en serie" de Guarne] [[RCN Radio]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. The other people were murdered in the same way, including children who were 5 and 7 years respectively, all of whom were killed in November 2015.Natalio Cosoy (20 de junio de 2016). [https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-36582249 Jaime Iván Martínez Betancur, el colombiano que confesó ser asesino en serie y haber matado al menos a 20 personas] [[BBC]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. It was also established that María Gladis Arango was another victim, who disappeared in mid-January of 2016 in a village called Hoja Anche de Guarne, in [[Guarne]]. Due to Arango's disappearance, the Colombian authorities imposed an "assurance measure for the crime of enforced disappearance", which allowed for a more detailed follow-up investigation. According to the investigating authorities, Martínez buried most of his victims in [[Potter's field|potter's fields]] at depths of 3 meters, wrapped in several years of canvas, at a farm where he worked, as a method to forcibly hide the bodies. Nevertheless, according to his own confessions, he claimed that others were buried in two farms near the place where he lived.[https://www.elheraldo.co/nacional/cti-capturo-jaime-martinez-el-asesino-en-serie-del-municipio-de-guarne-antioquia-267521 CTI capturó a Jaime Martínez, el asesino en serie del municipio de Guarne, Antioquia] [[El Heraldo (Colombia)|''El Heraldo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.[https://www.rcnradio.com/colombia/antioquia/condenan-42-anos-prision-al-llamado-asesino-serie-guarne Condenan a 42 años de prisión al llamado "asesino en serie" de Guarne] [[RCN Radio]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.[https://www.elnuevosiglo.com.co/articulos/6-2016-ser%C3%ADan-25-las-v%C3%ADctimas-del-asesino-de-guarne Serían 25 las víctimas del asesino de Guarne] ''[[El Nuevo Siglo]]''. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. He also collected objects and personal elements of his victims such as watches, smart phones, jewelry, etc.[https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-16624903 Asesino en serie en Guarne guardaba prendas de sus víctimas] [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|''El Tiempo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.Natalio Cosoy (20 de junio de 2016). [https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-36582249 Jaime Iván Martínez Betancur, el colombiano que confesó ser asesino en serie y haber matado al menos a 20 personas] [[BBC]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. He was captured in Guarne by specialized personnel of the CTI, very close to the eastern subregion of Antioquia Department in a farm where he worked as a [[majordomo]] and guard, the same place where he committed several of the murders, although it is believed that he has killed others in [[Medellín]] and [[Valle del Cauca Department]].[https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-16623809 Capturan en Antioquia a asesino en serie que mató a 20 personas] [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|''El Tiempo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019.Natalio Cosoy (20 de junio de 2016). [https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-36582249 Jaime Iván Martínez Betancur, el colombiano que confesó ser asesino en serie y haber matado al menos a 20 personas] [[BBC]]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. Martínez had worked as a farmer, but also held other jobs in surveillance and gardening.[https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-16624903 Asesino en serie en Guarne guardaba prendas de sus víctimas] [[El Tiempo (Colombia)|''El Tiempo'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. == Condemnation == Martínez was sentenced to 42 years imprisonment for the murder of Arango, Gil and her two children. He was charged with several crimes, including [[forced disappearance]] and murder.[https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/nacional/antioquia/el-asesino-de-guarne-pagara-42-anos-de-prision-articulo-675847 El asesino de Guarne pagará 42 años de prisión] [[El Espectador (periódico)|''El Espectador'']]. Consultado el 24 de mayo de 2019. == See also == * [[List of serial killers by country]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iván Martínez, Jaime}} [[Category:Colombian serial killers]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Colombia]] [[Category:21st-century criminals]] [[Category:Filicides]] [[Category:Uxoricides]] [[Category:People from Caldas Department]] [[Category:Pages with unreviewed translations]]

{{short description|Colombian serial killer}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Luis Alberto Malagón Suárez | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = "The Sadist of Rincón" | birth_date = ??? | birth_place = [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = | victims = 6 | beginyear = 1995 | endyear = 2001 | country = [[Colombia]] | states = [[Bogotá]] | apprehended = 2012 | imprisoned = Acacías Prison, [[Meta Department]] }} '''Luis Alberto Malagón Suárez''' is a [[Colombia|Colombian]] rapist and [[serial killer]]. Known as '''The Sadist of Rincón''', he kidnapped, raped and murdered 5 minors, as well as his wife.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.msn.com/es-co/noticias/colombia/los-peores-asesinos-seriales-de-la-historia-de-colombia/ss-AApDlWV?parent-title=ministro-botero-en-el-ojo-del-hurac%C3%A1n&parent-ns=ar&parent-content-id=BBWnPIW&fullscreen=true#image=8|title=The worst serial killers in the history of Colombia|publisher=[[MSN]]|accessdate=August 26, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref> It is believed that he carried out the murders between 1995 and 1997 in the town of [[Suba, Bogotá|Suba]], during which he dismembered his victims and disposed of their remains in [[Bin bag|bin bags]].<ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://www.cablenoticias.tv/vernoticia.asp?wplaca=75427&fb_comment_id=1071144556299277_1071335642946835|title=These are serial killers that frightened Colombia|publisher=[[Cablenoticias]]|accessdate=August 26, 2019|language=Spanish}}{{Dead link|date=March 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
He is currently held in Acacías Prison, in the [[Meta Department]], for the murder of his wife.<ref name=sad>{{Citeweb|url=http://www.radiosantafe.com/2014/04/10/piden-condena-contra-hombre-que-abuso-y-desaparecio-a-5-ninas-de-suba/|title=They're asking for a sentence against a man who abused and killed 5 girls from Suba|publisher=[[Radio Santa Fe]]|accessdate=August 27, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref>
== Murders == According to the authorities' investigations, Malagón Suárez committed the murders in the 1990s, in the town of Suba. The victims were identified as Yulie Yesenia Chacón, Andrea García López, Nina Johana Moncada, Yolanda Perdomo and Lid Consuelo Pineda, all minors who lived in the Rincón neighborhood.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.publimetro.co/co/bogota/2018/03/07/abusadores-y-asesinos-en-serie-en-colombia.html|title=In the minds of the cruelest murderers and abusers of Colombia|author=Ginna Rincón and Pamela López|publisher=Publiometro|accessdate=August 27, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref> An investigator of the [[Administrative Department of Security|DAS]] affirmed that it took 4 years of investigations so Malagón Suárez could be captured; his daughter also told the authorities that in one of the rooms of the house where they lived, constant screams were heard, which Luis claimed came from the neighborhood cats.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.infobae.com/america/colombia/2018/05/12/el-cruel-escenario-de-tortura-al-que-han-sido-sometidos-los-ninos-en-la-historia-de-colombia/|title=The cruel scene of torture of which children have been subjected in the history of Colombia|author=Adriana Chica|publisher=[[Infobae]]|accessdate=August 27, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref> Finally, the DAS finished the investigation and conducted a search of the house, in which they found various belongings of the victims, among them - clothes, jewels, semen from the killer, hair, saliva and a sharp object.<ref name=suba>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1336175|title=Murderer of Suba girls captured|publisher=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]|accessdate=August 27, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref> It is believed that the bodies of the murdered children were placed inside bin bags and hidden, since they were never found.<ref name=suba/> One of Malagón's daughters also claimed that he would take the teenage girls to his residence, where he subsequently abuse them, tying up their hands and feet.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/fiscalia-pide-condenar-luis-alberto-malagon-suarez-por-muerte-de-cinco-ninas/383297-3|title=Condemnation requested for alleged killer of Suba girls|publisher=[[Semana]]|accessdate=August 27, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref> Despite this, the judge presiding over the case dismissed it, resulting in Malagón Suárez's acquittal.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=https://noticias.canalrcn.com/nacional-justicia/absuelven-unico-sospechoso-desaparicion-cinco-ninas|title=Absolutely only suspect ind disappearance of five girls|publisher=RCN News|accessdate=August 27, 2019|language=Spanish}}</ref>
On February 19, 2001, Malagón Suárez murdered his wife in front of his daughters, stabbing her several times. Previously, he had bound and gagged her in the home.<ref name=suba/>
== Capture == Malagón Suárez was captured in 2012, and prosecuted for killing his wife. He was convicted, and sent off to Acacías Prison in Meta.<ref name=sad/>
== See also == * [[Luis Garavito]]
