{{Infobox serial killer | name = Jorge Humberto Martínez Córtez | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = "El Matanovias"
"Joy Drago"
"Joy Agote" | birth_date = 1978 | birth_place = [[Mexico]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = Awaiting sentencing | victims = 2-3 | beginyear = 2011 | endyear = 2014 | country = [[Mexico]] | states = | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Jorge Humberto Martínez Córtez''' (born 1978) is a supposed [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[serial killer]]. == Biography == Jorge Humberto Martínez Córtez is suspected of killing 2 to 3 women between 2011 and 2014, as well as an [[attempted murder]] against another woman which caused serious injuries. All of his victims were his romantic partners. He was nicknamed "El Matanovias".{{citeweb|title=Who is "El Matanovias?"|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/perfil_matanovias-jorge_humberto_martinez-detenido_guatemala-milenio-noticias_0_1054094963.html|newspaper=Milenio|publisher=Grupo Milenio|date=24 October 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish}}{{citeweb|title=Who is and why was "El Matanovias" stopped?|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com.mx/2017/10/25/quien-es-y-por-que-fue-detenido-el-mata-novias_a_23256262/|newspaper=HuffPost|publisher=TheHuffingtonPost Holdings LLC|date=25 October 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327084527/https://www.huffingtonpost.com.mx/2017/10/25/quien-es-y-por-que-fue-detenido-el-mata-novias_a_23256262/|archive-date=27 March 2018|url-status=dead}} He strangled all of his victims on whom he used to exercise physical violence and tried to pass off the killings as suicides, cutting hair strands as possible trophies.{{citeweb|title=They discovered chilling publications in Facebook of "El Matanovias" of CDMX (PHOTOS)|url=http://elmanana.mx/noticia/129870/Descubren-escalofriantes-publicaciones-en-Facebook-del-Matanovias-de-CDMX-(FOTOS).html|newspaper=El Mañana Nacional|publisher=Editora Argos S.A. de C.V.|date=14 March 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180403173548/http://elmanana.mx/noticia/129870/Descubren-escalofriantes-publicaciones-en-Facebook-del-Matanovias-de-CDMX-(FOTOS).html|archive-date=3 April 2018|url-status=dead}}{{citeweb|title="Matanovias" destroyed my sister's life in two months|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/matanovias-jorge_humberto-camira-yang-estrangula-milenio-noticias_0_919708493.html|newspaper=Milenio|publisher=Grupo Milenio|date=15 March 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish}} In his social networks he called himself "Joy Drago" or "Joy Agote", according to leaks to the media - he published threats against several of his victims, such as images of women in an [[ofrenda]] or having changed their status to "Widowed" before they died.{{citeweb|title=The disturbing content that "the Matanovias" shared on Facebook|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/comunidad/2017/10/26/1197049|newspaper=Excélsior|publisher=Grupo Imagen|date=26 October 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish}} In 2016, he was denounced for the murder of his last victim but Martínez fled, and a red [[Interpol]] file was issued; he was arrested in October 2017, in [[Izabal Department|Izabal]], [[Guatemala]].{{citeweb|title=Interpol captures in Guatemala the "Matanovias"; the PGJ-CDMX will request your transfer|url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/508643/interpol-captura-en-guatemala-al-matanovias-la-pgj-cdmx-solicitara-traslado|newspaper=[[Proceso (magazine)|Proceso]]|publisher=Comunicación e Información S.A. de C.V|date=24 October 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish}}{{citeweb|first=José|last=Meléndez|title=Delivered to "Matanovias" to the PGR in Guatemala|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/metropoli/cdmx/entregan-el-matanovias-pgr-en-guatemala|newspaper=El Universal|publisher=El Universal|date=15 October 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish}} On October 26, 2017, he was charged with murder, and is awaiting sentencing. He has at least 2 more charges pending, one for homicide and one for injuries.{{citeweb|title=They link the process to "El Matanovias", but only for the feminicide of one of their victims|url=https://www.proceso.com.mx/508932/vinculan-a-proceso-a-matanovias-feminicidio-una-sus-victimas|newspaper=Proceso|publisher=Comunicación e Información S.A. de C.V|date=26 October 2017|accessdate=2 April 2018|language=Spanish}} == References == {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martinez Córtez, Jorge Humberto}} [[Category:Mexican serial killers]] [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:Mexican murderers]] [[Category:Living people]] {{mexico-stub}}

{{Infobox serial killer |name=Alejandro Máynez |image= |caption= |birth_name=Armando Martínez |alias= |birth_date=c. 1970s |birth_place=[[Mexico]] |death_date= |death_place= |cause= |conviction= |sentence= |victims= |beginyear=1980s |endyear=1990 |country=[[Mexico]] |states= |apprehended= }} '''Alejandro Máynez''' (born '''Armando Martínez''' c. 1970s) is a [[Mexicans|Mexican]] [[serial killer]] and fugitive.<ref>{{cite book |first=Diana |last=Washington Váldez |title=Cosechja de mujeres: safarí en el desierto mexicano |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pr5HAAAAYAAJ&q=alejandro+maynez&dq=alejandro+maynez&hl=es&sa=X&ei=oVGhT-XGI-ia2AWHmLXACQ&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA |publisher=University of Texas |year=2005 |isbn=9706519882 |pages=168-170}}</ref> Along with Ana Benavides<ref name="Moreno"/> and Melchor Máynez,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://contralinea.info/archivo-revista/index.php/2010/10/17/feminicidios-en-juarez-policias-fabrican-culpables/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101018150705/http://contralinea.info/archivo-revista/index.php/2010/10/17/feminicidios-en-juarez-policias-fabrican-culpables/ |archive-date=2010-10-18 |url-status=dead|title=Feminicidios en Juárez: policías fabrican culpables|author=Santiago Gallur Santorum|date=17 October 2010|publisher=Contralínea 204|accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref> he killed at least two women in [[Ciudad Juárez]], but he is believed to be responsible for 50 victims in all. His murders are organized and motivated by sexual compulsion, committed as part of a group.
==Beginnings== Alejandro was an orphan. He was baptized '''Armando Martínez'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/ciudad_juarez/10.html|title=Ciudad Juarez:The Serial Killer's Playground (pg. 10)|author=Michael Newton|publisher=TruTV|accessdate=30 April 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504235135/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/ciudad_juarez/10.html|archive-date=2012-05-04|url-status=dead}}</ref> He spent a portion of his childhood in orphanages in the United States. During the 1970s, he was adopted by Guillermo Máynez, a [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] business entrepreneur and owner of approximately 20 bars and nightclubs in [[Ciudad Juárez|Juárez]], and his family, who gave him his surname and changed his name to Alejandro.<ref name="Moreno">{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2002/11/04/articulos/51_juarez.htm|title=Alguien muy poderoso, con protección policiaca, tras el impune femicidio en Ciudad Juárez: peritos y activistas|author=Rubén Villalpando Moreno|date=2002|publisher=La Jornada|accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref>
==Crimes== During the 1980s and 1990s, Alejandro and Melchor, cousins, joined a gang of drug and jewelry traffickers that smuggled contraband into the United States. Supposedly, they were under the protection of the Chihuahuan government headed by [[Francisco Barrio]].<ref name="Rivera">{{cite web|url=http://asesinosenseriebios.blogspot.mx/2009/09/el-depredador-de-ciudad-juarez-mexico.html|title="El Depredador de Ciudad Juárez" (México)|author=Horacio B. Rivera|date=29 September 2009|publisher=Enciclopedia de los asesinos en serie|accessdate=30 April 2014}}</ref>
In 1999, two former police officers, Víctor Valenzuela and Ramiro Romero Gómez, of the state and federal police, started a new department that specialized in femicides, accusing Alejandro Máynez of the deaths of several women:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hoy.com.ec/especial/2004/juarez/juarez.htm |title=Las muertas de Juárez (4th presentation) |author=Guadalupe Elizalde |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122220743/http://www.hoy.com.ec/especial/2004/juarez/juarez.htm |archivedate=2013-01-22 }}</ref>
{{quotation|We were in a club when he told us that he and another person were involved in raping and murdering women... (Valenzuela, Víctor; 1999)<ref name="Moreno"/>}}
According to Valenzuela and Romero, Máynez had enjoyed the protection of the police in his crimes. That year, Valenzuela was incarcerated on charges of narcotics sales, and Romero was executed.<ref name="Rivera"/> Earlier, in 1995, [[Abdul Latif Sharif]] was arrested and faced charges for tens of femicides; he claimed to be innocent and accused Máynez of being the true "Juárez Ripper".
===Alejandro and Melchor=== The Máynez cousins had begun their career as serial killers in 1988, alongside their activities as traffickers. At some point, they separated and began to kill in turns.
===Alejandro and Ana=== In 1998, Alejandro met Ana Benavides, who was working as a waitress at one of his family's bars. Máynez's known victims also were employed in family businesses. Instead of becoming a victim, it turned out that Ana and he shared certain proclivities. Ana was a devil-worshipping fanatic who had already claimed the lives of three people. She quickly began to take an active part in Máynez's murders.<ref>{{cite book |last= Washington Valdez|first= Diana|date= 2006|title= The Killing Fields: Harvest of Women|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=UBA5tD8FVpUC&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=ana+benavides+y+alejandro+maynez&source=bl&ots=M6qV6-pbPR&sig=xMcer8g_OVPZGxNb0kVFxGE0K78&hl=es&sa=X&ei=kdujT8iKO4rbgQfK3vmkCQ&ved=0CF8Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=ana%20benavides%20y%20alejandro%20maynez&f=false|location= |publisher= |page= 147–150|isbn= 978-0-6151-4008-7|accessdate= 19 October 2014}}</ref>
==''"El diario de Richie"''== In 1995, a book was unveiled by an unknown author using the pseudonym "Richie". The book painstakingly compiled the events and details of several dozen murders. It is thought that Alejandro Máynez is the author of this book.<ref>{{cite book|last= Gónzalez Rodríguez|first= Sergio|date= 2003|title= Asesinos de mujeres en Ciudad Juárez|url= http://www.nodo50.org/pchiapas/mexico/noticias/juarez.htm|publisher= Geocities|isbn= 978-0-6151-4008-7|accessdate= 19 October 2014|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120615130656/http://www.nodo50.org/pchiapas/mexico/noticias/juarez.htm|archive-date= 2012-06-15|url-status= dead}}</ref>
According to the manuscript, many of the women who were murdered in Juárez were killed during orgies arranged by members of organized crime, at which they used the murders as material for [[snuff film]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almargen.com.mx/notas.php?IDNOTA=731 |title=Las muertas de Juárez de Víctor Ronquillo: el morbo de la razón cínica |last1=García-García |first1=José Manuel |date=23 March 2005 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006141646/http://www.almargen.com.mx/notas.php?IDNOTA=731 |archivedate=6 October 2014 }}</ref>

{{short description|Moroccan serial killer}} {{more footnotes|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Hadj Mohammed Mesfewi | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = The Marrakesh Arch-Killer | birth_date = between 1850s and 1870s | birth_place = [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]] | death_date = June 13, 1906 | death_place = Marrakesh, Morocco | cause = [[Execution]] | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = [[Death]] | victims = 36+ | beginyear = | endyear = 1906 | country = [[Morocco]] | states = April 1906 | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Hadj Mohammed Mesfewi '''(died June 13, 1906), called the "[[Marrakesh]] Arch-Killer", was a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] [[serial killer]] who murdered at least 36 women.
== Murders and execution == Mesfewi worked as a [[Shoemaking|shoemaker]] and trader. Supported by a 70-year-old woman named Rahali, he invited women to eat, drugged them, and killed them in their sleep.
26 corpses mutilated with a [[dagger]] were found buried under his shop, while the other ten could be discovered under another property he owned. He robbed many of his victims to enrich himself.
His execution on May 2, 1906, was supposed to be done by [[crucifixion]], but since foreign diplomats considered this method too brutal, Mesfewi was walled on June 11, 1906, in Marrakesh, and died two days later.

{{more citations needed|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Zdzisław Marchwicki | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = "The Zagłębie vampire" | birth_date = {{Birth date|1927|10|18}} | birth_place = [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]], [[Poland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1977|04|29|1927|10|18}} | death_place = [[Katowice]], [[Poland]] | cause = [[Execution]] | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = [[Death]] | victims = 14 | beginyear = 1964 | endyear = 1970 | country = [[Poland]] | states = | apprehended = 1972 | imprisoned = }} '''Zdzisław Marchwicki''' (October 18, 1927 – April 29, 1977), called the "[[Zagłębie Dąbrowskie|Zagłębie]] [[vampire]]",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rp.pl/Historia/309069927-Wampir-zZaglebia-Historia-zbrodni.html|title=Wampir z Zagłębia. Historia zbrodni|website=www.rp.pl|language=pl|access-date=2019-09-20}}</ref> was an alleged Polish [[serial killer]].
He was born in 1927 in [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]] to a lower-class family. His father went through five marriages in which four children were born—three brothers and a sister—all of whom were later charged along with Zdzisław for criminal conspiracy, robbery and obstructing justice.
Marchwicki was charged of killings committed in the following areas: in the neighbourhoods of [[Czeladź]], [[Będzin]], and adjoining towns in Zagłębie Dąbrowskie and [[Upper Silesia]]. The murders started in 1964 and continued, with occasional breaks, until late 1970.<ref>http://www.murderpedia.org/male.M/m/marchwicki-zdzislaw.htm</ref>
Having been arrested in early 1972, Marchwicki was charged with the murder of fourteen women and the attempted murder of another six, but one attempted murder charge was not proven.<ref>https://www.truecrimelibrary.com/crimearticle/zdislaw-and-hendryck-marchwicki/</ref>
After a highly publicized show trial which lasted for 10 months, Marchwicki received the death sentence in July 1975. His execution took place in 1977 in [[Katowice]], [[Poland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dabrowagornicza.naszemiasto.pl/zdzislaw-marchwicki-quotwampir-z-zaglebiaquot-byl-gornikiem/ar/c1-1509893|title=Zdzisław Marchwicki - "wampir z Zagłębia" był górnikiem w kopalni Zawadzki w Dąbrowie Górniczej|last=Redakcja|date=2012-08-18|website=Dąbrowa Górnicza Nasze Miasto|language=pl-PL|access-date=2019-09-20}}</ref>
Zdzisław's brother Jan Marchwicki also received the death penalty, while his third brother Henryk was sentenced to 25 years for taking part in a conspiracy to commit murder. The half-sister, Halina, got a three-year prison sentence for receiving stolen things such as watches and pens that she knew came from Zdzisław's victims.
Criminal penalties were given out to Halina's son, also called Zdzisław, for failing to inform the police about the murder conspiracies.<ref>http://killer.radom.net/~sermord/New/zbrodnia.php-dzial=mordercy&dane=MarchwickiZdzislaw.htm</ref>
One of Marchwicki's murder victims was the niece of [[Edward Gierek]], who was then the Upper Silesian communist party leader. However, the prosecution and the police investigators denied being pressured by political forces in the criminal prosecution of Zdzisław Marchwicki.

{{Infobox serial killer | name = Henryk Moruś | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = 1943 | birth_place = [[Sulejów]], [[Poland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|08|18|1943}} | death_place = [[Czarne]], [[Poland]] | cause = [[Heart failure]] | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = [[Death]] | victims = 7 | beginyear = 1986 | endyear =1992 | country = [[Poland]] | states = [[Piotrków Voivodeship]] | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Henryk Moruś''' (born 1943 in [[Sulejów]] - died August 18, 2013 in [[Czarne]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] [[serial killer]] who was convicted in 1993 for committing seven murders in the territory of [[Piotrków Voivodeship]]. He was the last prisoner to be sentenced to death in Poland in accordance with the European Convention of Human Rights.<ref name="rzepa2001">tygodnik ''[//pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rzeczpospolita_(gazeta) Rzeczpospolita]'', wydanie 980425, 2001 r.</ref><ref name="piotrkow">{{cite web|title=Morderca z Sulejowa bez łaski|url=http://piotrkowtrybunalski.naszemiasto.pl/wydarzenia/865547.html|agency="Dziennik Łódzki", przedruk portal wp.pl|date=19 June 2008|accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
== Investigation == Henryk Moruś was arrested in 1992. Initially he confessed to all seven murders that were attributed to him, citing that material problems with his family was his motive. However, he declared he was innocent at the pre-trial investigation.
The prosecutor accused him of shooting seven people for robbery with his carbine. The first murder was to carried out in 1986, and the next in the first half of 1992.<ref name="rzepa2001" /><ref name="MK997">''[//pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magazyn_Kryminalny_997 Magazyn Kryminalny 997]'', odcinek nr. 205, 9 grudnia 1999 r.</ref> Henryk Moruś' victims were:
* Teresa Grabowska (in 1986) * A 60-year old saleswoman from [[Piotrków Trybunalski]], murdered in her own store * Zdzisława and Mieczysław Beśkowie (married couple from Sulejów), killed in their own home's bedroom, with the woman being pregnant in the third month<ref name="7dni">{{cite web|title=Tu nikt go nie ułaskawi...|url=http://egazeta.dziennik.lodz.pl/N6832_2008/06/06/2008-06-06_Tygodnik_7_Dni_Wydanie_B.pdf|author=Karolina Wojna|agency=tygodnik "7 Dni"|date=6 June 2008|accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref> * Józef Jęcek, a pensioner from [[Ciechomin]] * Jarosław Kszczot, a cement trader from [[Czarnocin, Łódź Voivodeship|Czarnocin]] * Andrzej Kłosiński, owner of an office in [[Koluszki]].
During the long-lasting court proceedings, the accused did not speak, did not show remorse and made offensive gestures, which suggested a lack of senses (which, however, did not confirm anything). Expert psychiatrists recognized him as sane and completely accountable for his actions - they did not see him as having the capacity for higher feelings though. According to his family, he was a good husband and caring father of three children. In 1993, the Provincial Court of Piotrków Trybunalski sentenced Henryk Moruś for four murders to the death penalty with indefinite deprivation of public rights, and for three other murders and three offenses (theft, illegal alcohol and illegal possession of a firearm without a permit) to 25 years imprisonment.<ref name="rzepa1994">{{cite web|title=Sprawa Morusia znów na wokandzie|url=http://new-arch.rp.pl/artykul/27088_Sprawa_Morusia_znow_na_wokandzie.html|author=Marian Strzelecki|agency=tygodnik "Rzeczpospolita"|date=17 September 1994|accessdate=19 January 2010}}</ref>
== Appeals == On December 3, 1993, in the proceedings before the second instance at the [[Łódź]] Court of Appeal, the sentence was lifted, returning the case for re-examination, stating that the ruling of the Piotrków court was affected by significant deficiencies. The court came to the decision that only Andrzej Kłosiński's murder could be proven at first, which was helped by admission of Moruś, who initially denied any involvement before the court. It has also not been determined whether one or more people participated in the murder, as three witnesses gave different stories. The court re-imposed the same penalty in 1995.
Two separate appeals lodged by the defenders accused the court of many contradictions contained in the court's assessment and questioned the death penalty in the current moratorium on its execution. The court of appeal, which considered defense applications, supplemented (as a rarity) evidence of new expert opinions. Ultimately, however, the lower sentence was upheld. The accused's last words were that he had not killed anyone, and that the sentence was given coldly.
In the justification, the court stressed the causal relationship between the evidence and the assessment of the first sentence. The court also issued a verdict that the death penalty does not contradict Art. 2 of the European Convention on Human Rights, because (according to the law), it allows for it under Polish law, and the moratorium only concerns the periodic execution of the death penalty. Defending attorney Wiktor Celler announced that he would appeal for cassation. Finally, after the abolition of the death penalty in Poland with the enforcing of the Penal Code in 1998, it was turned into a life sentence for Henryk Moruś.<ref name="ziemiapiotrkowska">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ziemiapiotrkowska.pl/index.php?tydzien=173|title=Moruś will be behind bars.|author=Mariusz Jakubek|publisher="Ziemia Piotrkowska" Weekly|date=18 June 2008|access-date=19 January 2010}}</ref>
== Punishment and application for pardon == He was detained in a prison for recidivists in a seven-person cell in the [[Wołów Prison]]. His behaviour in penitentiary services was so good that he used the right to work, sewing leather balls in the sewing room.<ref name="wp">{{Cite web|url=http://wiadomosci.wp.pl/arcyzbrodniarz-prosi-lecha-kaczynskiego-o-laske-6032724001879169a|title=The aristocrat asks Lech Kaczyński for grace.|author=Marek Okolny|publisher="Dziennik Łódzki"|date=30 May 2008|access-date=19 January 2010}}</ref> In 2008, he applied for a pardon to president [[Lech Kaczyński]]. He emphasized that the punishment changed his life a lot, he regrets what he did, he became a [[Jehovah's witness]] in prison and would like to spend the rest of his life there.<ref name="dl">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dzienniklodzki.pl/artykul/986609,bezwgledny-morderca-z-sulejowa-nie-zyje-henryk-morus-zmarl-w-wiezieniu,id,t.html|title=The ruthless murderer from Sulejów is dead. Henryk Moruś died in prison.|author=Marek Okolny|publisher=dzienniklodzki.pl|date=16 September 2013|access-date=9 January 2017}}</ref> The Łódź Court of Appeal issued a negative opinion on the pardon application, just the like the District Court in Piotrków - it was decided to leave the request without further progress. In November 2009, Moruś was moved due to health complications from [[Wołów]] to [[Wrocław]].<ref name="autonazwa1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.epiotrkow.pl/news/Morderca-z-Sulejowa-przewieziony-do-Wroclawia,3206|title=A Murderer from Sulejów transported to Wrocław|author=Marek Okolny|publisher=E.Piotrków.pl|date=23 November 2003|access-date=19 January 2010}}</ref>
== Death == Moruś died on August 18, 2013 in the prison hospital of Czarne. He was 70 years old. The most probable cause of death was atherosclerosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy or heart failure. The family did not pick up his corpse, so his burial was organised by the prison. Henryk Moruś was buried in the municipal cemetery at Sienkiewicz Street in [[Człuchów]].<ref>Marek Obszarny: Henryk Moruś, the murderer of seven people, has died in prison. "Dziennik Łódzki", 7–8 September 2013</ref>{{R|dl}}

Kim są więźniowie skazani na najwyższy wymiar kary? Lizut: "W każdym z nich jest inna historia"''|date=8 May 2019}} where is sentenced to [[life imprisonment]]. == Biography == Musiatowicz grew up in a normal household in [[Zabrze]], [[Upper Silesia]]. At the age of 15, he ran away from home and went to [[Katowice]], where he met Tadeusz O., a 52-year-old homosexual who took him under his roof and gave him little money. In 2002, when Musiatowicz was 16, with a context of financial disputes, he hit Tadeusz on the head with a hammer. Leaving him unconscious, the youngster then set the apartment on fire. Tadeusz O. later died in the hospital. Because he was a minor at the time of the crime, Musiatowicz was sentenced to only 6 years imprisonment. After leaving prison, his behavior worsened, and he began attacking shops. In 2014, he tried to rob a grocery store, terrifying the saleswoman by putting a knife to her neck, but was tackled by a customer. He later said that he was ready to cut the woman's throat if she didn't give him any money: {| class="cytat-d" style="margin:0 auto; width:auto; background-color:inherit; border:0; padding: 0 5%;" | style="color:rgb(178, 183, 242); font:bold 40px 'Times New Roman',serif; vertical-align:bottom;" |„ |
''I consider myself a man without conscience''.
| style="color:rgb(178, 183, 242); font:bold 40px 'Times New Roman',serif; vertical-align:top;" |” |} He made assaults, always with either knives or an [[air gun]]. The psychologist later him as suffering from an [[antisocial personality disorder]]. {| class="cytat-d" style="margin:0 auto; width:auto; background-color:inherit; border:0; padding: 0 5%;" | style="color:rgb(178, 183, 242); font:bold 40px 'Times New Roman',serif; vertical-align:bottom;" |„ |
''For me, killing a human is like spitting''.
| style="color:rgb(178, 183, 242); font:bold 40px 'Times New Roman',serif; vertical-align:top;" |” |} [[File:Zabrze_Jaskółcza_17_01_2012_DSC_6604.jpg|thumb|Jaskółcza Street in Zabrze and the surrounding woods, in which Musiatowicz did his two murders]] Musiatowicz then made a "jump" in his life, forceful entering into the apartment of a businessman in Zabrze. He beat and tortured the man, until the victim told him where he had hidden 90,000 [[Polish złoty|złoty]] (ca. 18,000 £ or 23,500 US$). However, for an unknown reason, the businessman did not report the attack and Musiatowicz got away with it. The criminal was later detained by police and sentenced to 3 years imprisonment for robbing the grocery shop, after leaving prison only eight months earlier. His parents abandoned him, considering him a bandit, thief and psychopath. He had nowhere to go, and joined a group of homeless scrap collectors who camped in a forest at Jaskółcza Street in Zabrze. The men living there drank everything that contained alcohol. One day, one of them - Daniel, got drunk and went towards the campfire, losing his toes as a result. Eryk O. and Mirosław N., who were also homeless, did not help Daniel out. Musiatowicz told Daniel "they must be cleaned up". In February 2014, Musiatowicz killed Mirosław N. with an axe, and with Daniel's help, buried the body. Eryk O. initially avoided his demise because he was arrested, only to be released two months later. Immediately after, he was killed by Musiatowicz, and again, with Daniel's help, the body was buried near the previous one. Two days later, the police started searching the area, because they had received information about bodies being buried in the area. Musiatowicz was arrested, and psychiatric tests showed he was sane. He had no remorse for his actions. In 2015, he was sentenced to life imprisonment for the two murders. He will be able to apply for early release after forty years, in 2055. Daniel, for complicity in the killings, was sentenced to 15 years imprisonment. Musiatowicz is still considered dangerous, even while in prison: {| class="cytat-d" style="margin:0 auto; width:auto; background-color:inherit; border:0; padding: 0 5%;" | style="color:rgb(178, 183, 242); font:bold 40px 'Times New Roman',serif; vertical-align:bottom;" |„ |
''I do not know if I kill anyone in ten or fiteen years. I don't know what will happen in so many years.''.
| style="color:rgb(178, 183, 242); font:bold 40px 'Times New Roman',serif; vertical-align:top;" |” |} Musiatowicz specialized in armed robberies using a dangerous tool. He spent the majority of his adult life in penitentiary institutions, telling about his crimes in an episode of the documentary series "Life-Given", conducted by journalist Mikołaj Lizut. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Musiatowicz, Grzegorz}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:People from Zabrze]] [[Category:Polish serial killers]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by Poland]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Poland]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Poland]]

{{Infobox serial killer | name=Cedric Maake | image= | caption= | birthname=Maoupa Cedric Maake | alias=The Wemmer Pan Killer | birth_date=1965 | birth_place=[[South Africa]] | victims=27+ | country=[[South Africa]] | states=[[Gauteng]] | beginyear=1996 | endyear=1997 | apprehended=December 1997 | penalty=[[Life imprisonment|1,340 years imprisonment]] }}
'''Maoupa Cedric Maake''' (born 1965) (also known as the Wemmer Pan Killer) is a [[South African people|South African]] [[serial killer]]. He committed at least 27 murders throughout 1996 and 1997.
== Crimes ==
Maake is known as the "Wemmer Pan Killer" because it was in this area ([[Wemmer Pan]]) of [[Johannesburg]] that he targeted most of his victims, beginning in April 1996. At first the [[Brixton, Gauteng|Brixton]] Murder and Robbery Unit of the [[South African Police Service]] (SAPS), the unit primarily responsible for investigation of serial killers in the Johannesburg Police Area,<ref name="GIS">{{cite journal|author= Schmitz, PMU |author2= Cooper, AK|author3= Byleveld, P|author4= Rossmo, DK |title= Using GIS and Digital Aerial Photography to Assist in the Conviction of a Serial Killer |url=http://researchspace.csir.co.za/dspace/bitstream/10204/2778/1/Cooper1_2000.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=April 4, 2010 |location= Crime Mapping Research, 4th Annual International Conference , San Diego, California, USA}}</ref> did not link his crimes together, believing that they were the work of two separate serial killers due to the difference in patterns between the murders. During the investigation of Maake's murders, two separate [[criminal profile]]s were created; one for the "Wemmer Pan" murderer and one for "Hammer" murders.<ref name="SAPS">{{cite journal| last= Holtzhausen| first = Erica|editor= Gerda van den Bos|date=October 2006| title= World Records for How Quick They Nab Serial Killers| journal= SAPS Journal (South African Police Service Journal)| pages= 20–22| publisher= The Publications and Audiovisual Media Section of Communication and Liaison Services| location= Gauteng, South Africa| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011205733/http://www.saps.gov.za/docs_publs/publications/journal/oct2006/pg20_22.pdf | archivedate = October 11, 2007 | url = http://www.saps.gov.za/docs_publs/publications/journal/oct2006/index.htm| format= PDF | accessdate = April 4, 2010}}</ref>
The Wemmer Pan murders involved several patterns of victims. The first were men and women walking alone who Maake bludgeoned to death with rocks. The second group of [[Wemmer Pan]] victims were couples in cars around the Wemmer Pan area whom Maake would assault, shooting the men and [[Rape|raping]] the women.<ref name="SAPS" />
The second criminal profile the police created involved murders of [[tailor]]s in the inner city area, killed in their shops with hammers.<ref name="SAPS" /> The connection between the Wemmer Pan murders and the Hammer killings were made by Superintendent [[Piet Byleveld]] on 12 January 1998. Maake took Byleveld to a pawn shop in La Rochelle in the south of Johannesburg where he had sold the bicycle of Gerhard Lavoo, a victim in the Wemmer Pan murders, for R 120. The alias he used on the receipt was "Patrick Mokwena", the same alias he had used to check in a shirt at one of the tailors before Maake murdered him.<ref>{{cite book|last=Retief|first=Hanlie|title=Byleveld: Dossier of a Serial Sleuth|date=23 March 2012|publisher=Random House Struik|isbn=1415201439|page=130|url=https://www.amazon.com/Byleveld-Dossier-Serial-Hanlie-Retief/dp/1415201439/ref=tmm_pap_title_0}}</ref>
==Arrest== Maake was arrested in December 1997 as a suspect of the "Wemmer Pan" murders and initially acknowledged responsibility for the crimes. He cooperated with police officers on several occasions to lead them around the vicinity and point out the locations of his crimes. The data generated by this was later used with [[Geographic Information Systems]] (GIS) and [[crime mapping]] technology to provide diagrams of the geographical extent of the serial murders. The Wemmer Pan serial killer trial was one of the earliest uses of GIS to aid in court [[prosecution]] by the SAPS. [[Geographic profiling]] later revealed that the majority of Maake's murders were centered on his two residences, the place where he worked, and the residences of his brother and girlfriend.<ref name="GIS" />
Maake was charged with 36 counts of murder, 28 attempted murders, 15 counts of rape, 46 counts of [[aggravated robbery]], and other offenses relating to the unlawful possession of [[firearm]]s and [[ammunition]].<ref>{{cite web| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090321084643/http://www.saps.gov.za/docs_publs/publications/journal/mayjun05/extra_mile.htm | archivedate = March 21, 2009| url = http://www.saps.gov.za/docs_publs/publications/journal/mayjun05/extra_mile.htm | title= Going the Extra Mile In spite of…| first= Shaun| last= Chetty|date=May–June 2005| work= SAPS Journal (South African Police Service Journal)| publisher = The Publications and Audiovisual Media Section of Communication and Liaison Services.| location = Gauteng, South Africa| accessdate = April 4, 2010}}</ref> In court Maake pleaded not guilty to all charges.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/679141.stm|title=Serial killer jailed for 1,340 years |date=2000-03-16 |publisher=BBC.com |accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref> One month after his arrest he confessed to the "Hammer" murders.
On September 6, 2000, he was convicted of 27 murders, 26 attempted murders, 14 rapes, 41 aggravated robberies and many more less serious offenses.<ref name="BBC" /> He was found guilty of 114 of 134 charges in all and was sentenced to 27 [[life sentence]]s (one life sentence for each murder) plus 1159 years and 3 months imprisonment.<ref name="SAPS" /> In total, his sentence amounted to 1,340 years in prison.<ref name="BBC" />
==In media== Cedric Maake was featured in a 13-part [[M-Net]] television series called ''Criminal Minds'' hosted by [[Malcolm Gooding]].{{citation needed|date=April 2020}}

{{Infobox serial killer | name = Bulelani Mabhayi | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = 1974 | birth_place = [[South Africa]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = 25 years to [[life imprisonment]] | victims = 20 | beginyear = 2007 | endyear = 2012 | country = [[South Africa]] | states = [[Eastern Cape]] | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Bulelani Mabhayi''' (born 1974), also known as the "Monster of Tholeni", is a [[South Africa]]n [[serial killer]] and rapist who has been sentenced for the murder of 20 people.
== Murders and sentence == From May 2007 to August 11, 2012, Mabhayi killed 10 women and 9 children<ref name="D">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Serial-killer-pleads-guilty-to-20-murders-20130828|title=Serial killer pleads guilty to 20 murders|publisher=news24.com|date=2013-08-28|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> in the village of [[Tholeni]] in the [[Eastern Cape]].<ref name="B">{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/serial-killer-s-guilty-plea-shows-remorse-1.1570654#.U0Bom_ldVuw|title=Serial killer’s guilty plea ‘shows remorse’|publisher=Independent Online|date=2013-08-28|accessdate=5 April 2014|author=Seale, Lebogang}}</ref> A woman from another town was also murdered.<ref name="H">{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/news/we-will-never-forgive-you-serial-killer-told/|title=We will never forgive you, serial killer told|publisher=dispatch.co.za|date=2013-08-28|accessdate=5 April 2014|author=Solomon, Michelle}}</ref> He broke into houses at night, where there were no men. He would then rape some of his victims and then kill them with an axe or [[Machete|panga.]]
His youngest victim was 14 months old and his eldest was 79 years old.<ref name="C">{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/uncategorized/payback-as-tholeni-killer-is-sentenced-to-life-in-prison/|title=Payback as Tholeni killer is sentenced to life in prison|publisher=dispatch.co.za|date=4 September 2013|accessdate=5 April 2014|author=Solomon, Michelle}}</ref>
On May 17, 2010, Mabhayi and other local men over 16 years were tested and their fingerprints were taken. Mabhayi's fingerprints could not be taken because he had identification with him.<ref name="E">{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/the-cop-who-caught-the-monster-of-tholeni-1.1572605|title=The cop who caught the 'Monster of Tholeni'|publisher=Independent Online|date=4 September 2013|accessdate=5 April 2014|author=Seale, Lebogang}}</ref>
Mabhayi was found guilty of 20 counts of murder, 6 of rape and 10 of burglary.<ref name="A">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/monster-tholeni-south-africa-bulelani-mabhayi-sentenced-503688|title=South Africa's 'Monster of Tholeni' Bulelani Mabhayi Jailed for 625 Years for Rape and Murder Spree|publisher=International Business Times, VK|date=4 September 2013|accessdate=5 April 2014|author=Osborne, Hannah}}</ref> He was sentenced on September 3, 2013, from 25 years to [[life imprisonment]].

beginyear = 2000 | endyear = 2001 | country = [[South Africa]] | states = [[Gauteng]] | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Simon Majola''' (born 1968 in Mofolo, [[South Africa]]), known as '''The Bruma Lake Killer''', is a [[South Africa]]n robber and [[serial killer]] who, with accomplice Themba Nkosi, was responsible for the killings of at least 8 people in the vicinity of the Bruma Lake in [[Bruma, Gauteng]].<ref name=court>{{Cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/xArchive/Archive/Bruma-Lake-suspects-in-court-20010725|title=Bruma Lake suspects in court|publisher=[[News24]]|date=May 25, 2001}}</ref> Majola was given 8 life sentences, and is currently behind bars.<ref name=death>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/you-deserve-the-death-sentence-86734|title=You deserve the death sentence|author=Fikile-Ntsikelelo Moya|work=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]]|date=May 16, 2002}}</ref> ==Partnership== Majola, a married man with two children, already had previous convictions for housebreaking, assault and theft before the murders.<ref name=brag>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/im-the-bruma-lake-killer-brags-boyfriend-86888|title=I'm the Bruma Lake killer, brags boyfriend|author=Fikile-Ntsikelelo Moya and Gill Gifford|work=IOL|date=May 20, 2002}}</ref> While partying in [[Hillbrow]], he struck up a friendship with Themba Isaac Nkosi, of [[Vosloorus]].<ref name=dredge>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/|title=Dredging up the lake serial killers|work=The Saturday Star|date=September 10, 2011}}</ref> Their relationship quickly turned into a criminal one, with Majola and Nkosi robbing and killing people not only in Bruma Lake, but also in Rhodes Park, Bezuidenhout Park and Observatory Rift Park.<ref name=brag/><ref name=reign>{{Cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/xArchive/Archive/Bruma-pairs-reign-of-terror-20010219|title=Bruma pair's 'reign of terror'|author=Lizel Steenkamp|work=News24|date=February 20, 2001}}</ref> ==Murders== Between April 2000 and February 2001, couples' bodies were turning up in the Bruma Lake. Initially considered to be drug-related,<ref name=court/> the victims were apparently robbed of all cash, jewelry, bank cards, clothes and cell phones,<ref name=death/> before stones or bricks were tied to their feet and subsequently, they were drowned.<ref name=brag/> Majola and Nkosi would always work as a team, threatening their targets with knives and guns.<ref name=reign/> They always attacked people in the early evenings or late at night at party or picnic spots, while the victims were in their cars.<ref name=death/> Two of the bodies were in such an advanced state of decomposition that they were unrecognizable, with police additionally believing that they could have been foreigners.<ref name=death/><ref name=brag/>
Despite these events terrifying the locals, causing shops to close down and business losing lots of money,<ref name=death/> a majority of the incidents were never reported to the authorities, as some of the couples attacked were either gay or reluctant to come forward.<ref name=reign/> With the lack of any kind of evidence, including fingerprints, the case proved to be a particularly difficult one, even when it was handed down to Superintendent Piet Byleveld, a sleuth noted for his successful rate of solving cases.<ref name=dredge/> ==Capture and trial== On February 8, 2001, two men were arrested in [[Kensington, Gauteng|Kensington]] for the illegal possession of firearms. Those two men were Majola and Nkosi. When notified of the arrests, Byleveld immediately drove to the station in order to move the criminals to [[Brixton, Gauteng|Brixton]]. While in a separate car with Nkosi, he noticed the muscular man, who not so long ago was very cocky and considered his arrest as a joke, suddenly had begun to tremble. Later, when questioned separately, both criminals confessed to their crimes, including others of which they weren't suspected: including people robbed in Rhodes Park; the May 15, 2000 murder of a [[Baptist]] preacher and the murder of a mutual friend during a failed break-in. Majola and Nkosi also killed any associate who discovered what they were up to, killing them in the same way that they did with the other victims.<ref name=dredge/> Byleveld managed to connect them to at least 21 murders and attempted murders.<ref name=reign/>
The duo were brought to trial on September 2002. During the process, Nkosi's mother, Ruth Tshehlo, pleaded to the court to be lenient with her "first-born" child, as he was reliable.<ref name=brag/> Meanwhile, Majola denied all charges, blaming his convictions on [[white supremacy]].<ref name=death/> Neither criminal's tactics worked, as Majola was convicted on 8 counts of murder, 19 of armed robbery, and 5 of attempted murder; while Nkosi was found guilty of 4 murder charges, 14 of armed robbery, five of attempted murder and of assaulting his pregnant then-girlfriend, Jabulile Lushaba, to whom he had bragged of being the "Bruma Lake Killer".<ref name=brag/> Both of them were sentenced to life imprisonment.<ref name=death/> ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=SfYFYEWb62AC&pg=PT317&lpg=PT317&dq=Simon+Majola+murder|title=Serial Killers: The Method and Madness of Monsters|author=Peter Vronsky|date=2004|isbn=1101204621|author-link=Peter Vronsky}} * {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=aiq1-13V_CMC&pg=PA188&lpg=PA188&dq=Simon+Majola+murder|title=Portrait with Keys: The City of Johannesburg Unlocked|author=Ivan Vladislavic|date=2009|isbn=978-0393071511|author-link=Ivan Vladislavic}} * {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oAZbDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT173&lpg=PT173&dq=Simon+Majola+murder|title=Byleveld: dossier of a serial sleuth|author=Hanlie Retief|date=2011|isbn=978-1415203156}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Majola, Simon}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:South African serial killers]] [[Category:South African murderers]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by South Africa]] [[Category:People convicted of robbery]] [[Category:People convicted of attempted murder]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of South Africa]] [[Category:People from Soweto]]

{{short description|South African serial killer}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Fanuel Makamu | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = "Mpumalanga Serial Rapist" | birth_date = 1977 | birth_place = [[Acornhoek]], [[Mpumalanga]], [[South Africa]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = 165 years' imprisonment | victims = 6 | beginyear = February | endyear = September 2000 | country = [[South Africa]] | states = [[Mpumalanga]] | apprehended = September 14, 2000 | imprisoned = }}
'''Fanuel Makamu''' (born 1977 in [[Acornhoek]], [[Mpumalanga]]), known as the '''Mpumalanga Serial Rapist''', is a [[South Africa]]n robber, rapist and [[serial killer]]. Along with his accomplice, Henry Maile, the duo robbed, raped and killed women and nearby witnesses on streets between February and September 2000.<ref name=hell>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Woman-tells-of-rape-hell-20040420|title=Woman tells of rape hell|author=Zenzele Kuhlase|publisher=[[News24]]|date=20 April 2004}}</ref> Maile was killed during apprehension, and Makamu was sentenced to 165 years' imprisonment.
==Murders== Makamu and Maile started their crime spree in February 2000. They would rob and rape women on streets, and at times, shoot anybody accompanying their victims. On one such instance, on August 5, the criminals broke into a water pump station in Cottondale, where a security guard and his girlfriend were sleeping, shooting the man dead and raping the woman, killing her afterwards as well.<ref name=hell/>
In another case, a woman was walking towards her husband's work when the two men forced her to come with them, raping her at Magwagwaza High School in Mhala on May 11.<ref name=hell/>
One of the surviving victims testified about her encounter with the two men: she and a female friend were raped in Mhala on September 2, and overheard their attackers discussing how to kill them. However, Makamu and Maile simply took a cell phone and the women's clothes, and fled.<ref name=hell/> ==Capture and sentence== Eventually, while trying to evade arrest, Maile was killed by police raiding his house on September 14.<ref name=hell/><ref name=justice>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/justice-at-last-in-makamu-case-213775|title=Justice at last in Makamu case|publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]]|date=28 May 2004}}</ref> Makamu tried to flee, but was soon turned in by his mother after an outcry from the community.<ref name=sentence>{{Citeweb|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Serial-killer-gets-165-years-20040727|title=Serial killer gets 165 years|author=Zenzele Kuhlase and Oris Mnisi|publisher=[[News24]]|date=27 July 2004}}</ref>
He was charged with 10 counts of rape, 6 counts of murder, 5 counts of armed robbery, 2 counts of attempted murder, 3 counts of housebreaking, one of attempted robbery, one of attempted housebreaking, 2 of illegal possession of firearms, 2 of illegal possession of ammunition, one of malicious damage to property and one of attempt to escape from custody.<ref name=hell/> Makamu pled not guilty in front of the Circuit Court in [[Nelspruit]]; however, Judge Willy Serete found him guilty of 32 charges, acquitting him of 2 rape and robbery charges.<ref name=justice/><ref name=sentence/>
Makamu was given 8 life sentences and 165 years of imprisonment, much to the relief of the community and his mother, Joyce Makhubela. She said that her son got what he deserved for doing such horrible crimes, and upon leaving court with her 19-year-old daughter, Sibongile, both were treated warmly by her son's victims and their families. The mayor of [[Bushbuckridge]], Milton Morema, also expressed his relief with the sentence.<ref name=sentence/> ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox serial killer | name=Daisy de Melker | image= | caption= | birth_name=Daisy Louisa C. Hancorn-Smith | alias= | birth_date={{Birth date|1886|06|01}} | birth_place=[[Makana Local Municipality|Seven Fountains]], [[Cape Colony]] | death_date={{Dda|1932|12|30|1886|06|01}} | death_place = [[Pretoria]], [[Transvaal (province)|Transvaal]], [[Union of South Africa]] | cause=[[Hanging|Execution by hanging]] | victims=3 | country=[[South Africa]] | states= | beginyear=1923 | endyear=1932 | children=5 | spouse= 4 | apprehended=April 1932 | penalty= [[Death sentence|Death]] }}
'''Daisy Louisa C. de Melker''' (née '''Hancorn-Smith'''; 1 June 1886 – 30 December 1932) simply known as '''Daisy de Melker''', was a trained [[nurse]]<ref>[http://www.crimemagazine.com/daisy-de-melker-south-africas-first-serial-killer-0 Daisy de Melker: South Africa's First Serial Killer by Marilyn Z. Tomlins]</ref> who poisoned two husbands with [[strychnine]] for their life insurance money while living in [[Turffontein]], [[Johannesburg]], and then poisoned her only son with [[arsenic]] for reasons which are still unclear. She is the second woman to have been [[hanging|hanged]] in [[South Africa]].<ref>{{cite book| last=Marsh| first=Rob| title=Famous South African Crimes| pages=29–32| url=http://www.africacrime-mystery.co.za/books/fsac/index.htm| accessdate=2008-04-29}}</ref>
Daisy de Melker was accused of three murders but was only convicted of one, that of killing her son. The charges of poisoning her husbands were never proven in a court of law. It was William Sproat, the younger brother of her second husband, who accused her because he wanted Robert Sproat's will in favour of Daisy declared invalid. Daisy refused to refund an alleged loan from Mrs. Jane Sproat, Robert's mother, to Robert; she regarded it as a gift and argued that it was not stipulated in the will as a loan. William Sproat won the civil case regarding the will, which ran concurrently with the murder trial, and was awarded costs. Daisy withdrew on the date Justice Greenberg sentenced her for murder. William's was a [[Pyrrhic victory]] however. To pay her exorbitant legal costs, Daisy had to sell off all her assets. She was declared insolvent and was eventually buried in a prison pauper's grave.
==Early life== Daisy Hancorn-Smith was born at Seven Fountains near [[Grahamstown]], South Africa. She was one of eleven children. When she was twelve, she went to [[Bulawayo]], [[Rhodesia]] (now [[Zimbabwe]]) to live with her father and two of her brothers. Three years later, she became a boarder at the Good Hope Seminary School in [[Cape Town]]. She returned to Rhodesia in 1903, but apparently found rural life unexciting, because it was not long before she returned to South Africa and enrolled at the Berea Nursing Home in [[Durban]].
On one of her holidays in Rhodesia, she met and fell in love with a young man named Bert Fuller who was a civil servant in the Native Affairs Department at [[Kabwe|Broken Hill]]. They planned to marry in October 1907. However, Fuller contracted [[blackwater fever]] and died, with Daisy at his bedside, on the very day they had planned to marry. Fuller left a will bequeathing £100 to his fiancée.
In March 1909, about eighteen months after the death of Bert Fuller, Daisy married William Alfred Cowle, a plumber in [[Johannesburg]]. She was 22 and he was 36. The couple had five children, four of whom died. The first two were twins, who died in infancy; their third child died of an abscess on the liver; and the fourth suffered convulsions and bowel trouble and died at the age of 15 months. Their last, and only surviving child, Rhodes Cecil, was born in June 1911.
==First murder: William Cowle (first husband)== Early on the morning of 11 January 1923, William Cowle became ill soon after taking [[epsom salts]] prepared by his wife. The first doctor who attended him did not consider his condition to be serious and prescribed a [[bromide]] mixture. But Cowle's condition deteriorated rapidly. Not long after the doctor had left, he took a turn for the worse. His wife summoned the neighbors to help and called for another doctor. Cowle was in excruciating pain when the second doctor arrived. He foamed at the mouth, was blue in the face, and screamed in agony if anyone touched him, until he died.
Faced with these symptoms, the second doctor suspected [[strychnine]] [[poison]]ing and refused to sign the [[death certificate]]. A [[postmortem]] was subsequently performed by the acting District Surgeon, Dr. Fergus. The cause of death was certified to be [[chronic (medicine)|chronic]] [[nephritis]] and [[cerebral hemorrhage]]. Daisy Cowle, the sole beneficiary of her husband's will, inherited £1795.
==Second murder: Robert Sproat (second husband)== At the age of thirty-six, and three years to the day after the death of her first husband, Daisy Cowle married another plumber. His name was Robert Sproat and was ten years her senior. In October 1927, Robert Sproat became violently ill. He was in great agony and suffered severe [[spasm|muscle spasms]] similar to those experienced by William Cowle, but he recovered. A few weeks later, he suffered a second fatal attack after drinking some [[beer]] in the company of his wife and stepson, Rhodes. He died on 6 November 1927. Dr. Mallinick, the attending [[physician]], certified that the cause of death was [[arteriosclerosis]] and [[cerebral hemorrhage]]. No [[autopsy]] was performed. Following Robert Sproat's death, his widow inherited over £4000, plus a further £560 paid by his pension fund.
==Third murder: Rhodes Cecil Cowle (son)== On 21 January 1931, Daisy Sproat married for the third time. Her husband was a widower, Sydney Clarence de Melker, who, like her previous two husbands, was a [[plumber]].
Late in February 1932, Daisy de Melker had traveled from [[Germiston]] on the [[East Rand, Gauteng|East Rand]] to [[Turffontein]], to obtain arsenic from a [[pharmacist|chemist]]. She used her former name, Sproat, and claimed that she required the [[poison]] to destroy a sick [[cat]]. Less than a week later, on 2 March 1932, Rhodes fell ill at work after drinking coffee from a thermos flask which his mother had prepared for him. A fellow worker, James Webster, also become violently sick. Webster, who had drunk very little of the [[coffee]], recovered within a few days, but Rhodes died at home at midday on 5 March. A [[postmortem]] followed and the cause of death was given as [[cerebral malaria]]. Rhodes was buried at New Brixton cemetery the following day; on 1 April, de Melker received £100 from Rhodes' life insurance policy.
At the time of his death, Daisy de Melker's only son Rhodes Cowle was 20. His step-sister, Eileen de Melker, thought him lazy and remarked that he was often unwilling to get up for work in the morning. However, another witness at his mother's trial described him as "bright and conscientious" and a "real gentleman".{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}} Certainly the evidence conflicted, but none of it explained why Daisy de Melker decided to kill Rhodes. In the case of her first two husbands, the motive seemed clearly to be financial gain.
Rhodes seems to have been under the impression that he would come into an inheritance at the age of 21. One theory is that he was demanding more than Daisy could give him and was becoming a burden to her. The most obvious answer is that she simply didn't like him and that he was a disappointment to her. She had pampered him all his life, but he rarely showed her any consideration in return.
==Arrest, trial and execution== By this time, William Sproat (the brother of Daisy de Melker's second dead husband) had become suspicious and these suspicions were conveyed to the authorities. On 15 April 1932, the police obtained a court order permitting them to [[exhume]] the bodies of Rhodes Cowle, Robert Sproat and William Cowle.
The first body to be removed was that of Rhodes Cowle. The corpse was found to be in an unusually good state of preservation, which is characteristic of the presence of [[arsenic]] in large quantities.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} A state [[forensic pathology|forensic pathologist]] was able to isolate traces of arsenic in the [[viscera]], [[Vertebral column|backbone]] and [[hair]]. Although the bodies of William Cowle and Robert Sproat were largely decomposed, traces of [[strychnine]] were found in the [[vertebrae]] of each man. Their bones also had a pinkish discoloration, suggesting that the men had taken pink strychnine, which was common at the time.
Traces of arsenic were also found in the hair and fingernails of James Webster, Rhodes' colleague who had survived.
A week later, the police arrested de Melker and charged her with the [[murder]] of all three men. Public interest in the De Melker case grew, and the newspapers gave the story a great deal of coverage. The Turffontein chemist, Mr. Abraham Spilkin, from whom she had bought the arsenic that killed her son, recognized de Melker from a newspaper photograph as being "Mrs D.L. Sproat", who had signed the poisons register, and went to the police.
The de Melker trial lasted thirty days. Sixty witnesses were called for [[the Crown]] and less than half this number for the [[Defense (legal)|defense]]. To present the [[forensic evidence]], the Crown employed the services of Dr. J.M. Watt, an expert [[toxicologist]] and Professor of Pharmacology at the [[Witwatersrand University]]. In summing up, before giving his verdict, the [[judge]] pointed out that the Crown had been unable to prove conclusively that Cowle and Sproat had died of strychnine poisoning. "It does not convince me, nor does it convict the accused," he said.<ref>[http://www.truecrimelibrary.com/crime_series_show.php?series_number=13&id=1062 Execution By hanging:] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201074816/http://truecrimelibrary.com/crime_series_show.php?id=1062&series_number=13 |date=2010-12-01 }} Daisy de Melker, retrieved 1932/12/30</ref>
On the third count, however, he had come to the "inescapable conclusion" that de Melker had murdered her son. This was evident because: * Rhodes Cowle had died of arsenic poisoning * The coffee flask held traces of arsenic * The accused had put the arsenic into the flask * The defense of [[suicide]] was untenable
When the judge finally turned to pass sentence on de Melker, her face whitened but she still proclaimed her innocence.
Daisy de Melker (aged 46 years) was condemned to death by hanging. The sentence was carried out on the morning of 30 December 1932 at [[Pretoria|Pretoria Central Prison]].
==Daisy de Melker in popular culture== *In 1934, [[Sarah Gertrude Millin]] wrote the novel "Three Men Died," based on the de Melker case.<ref name="Millin">{{cite book | last=Millin | first=S.G.L. | title=Three Men Die: A Novel by Sarah Gertrude Millin | publisher=Chatto & Windus | year=1934 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VzUxAAAAIAAJ | access-date=16 October 2019 | page=}}</ref> *In 1993, a television mini-series was made about Daisy de Melker, with Susan Coetzer in the title role.<ref>{{cite video|date=1993| title=Daisy de melker| url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106652/| people=Annie Basson (Director), George Goldsmith (writer), Susan Coetzer (Daisy de Melker)| accessdate=2008-04-29| medium=Television Production}}</ref> *In September 2005, a [[drag (clothing)|drag]] musical "Daisy's Well Hung" starring [[Robert Coleman (American actor)|Robert Coleman]] as "Daisy" was staged at the Women's Jail on [[Constitution Hill, Johannesburg|Constitution Hill]] in Johannesburg, where de Melker had been imprisoned prior to her hanging. This show attempted to transform the dour figure of De Melker into a [[poltergeist]] of a husband-killing [[femme fatale]].<ref name="DaisySwings">{{cite web | last=Cohen | first=Taryn | title=Daisy swings live at Constitution Hill | website=Artslink | url=http://www.artlink.co.za/news_article.htm?contentID=22707 | access-date=16 October 2019}}</ref>

{{Infobox serial killer | name = Samuel Bongani Mfeka | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[South Africa]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = | victims = 6 | beginyear = 1993 | endyear = 1996 | country = [[South Africa]] | states = [[KwaZulu-Natal]] | apprehended = | imprisoned = }} '''Samuel Bongani Mfeka''' is a [[South Africa]]n [[serial killer]], who was arrested on September 8, 1996 in [[KwaZulu-Natal]] for rape.<ref>[https://books.google.fr/books?id=DwNVbOcTncwC&pg=PA381&lpg=PA381&dq=Samuel+Bongani+Mfeka&source=bl&ots=B1CDstVx7G&sig=5aEM3rhdFMLpkRsBjIOjB11U7BM&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=7KmAUu-KOJKZhQeghIDABg&ved=0CHkQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Samuel%20Bongani%20Mfeka&f=false Fiche de Bongani Mfeka] in ''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' par Michael Newton.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.fr/books?id=zM7ROzJPK2MC&pg=PA341&lpg=PA341&dq=%22Samuel+Bongani+Mfeka%22&source=bl&ots=8iPdOSj5yl&sig=pBYLTMIJnDxi4C0fgSxuMPyttSU&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=l6qAUq_pLsiihgfitYDgCw&ved=0CHYQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22Samuel%20Bongani%20Mfeka%22&f=false Samuel Bongani Mfeka] in ''The A to Z Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' par Harold Schechter.</ref>
While imprisoned he gave the locations of six places, where he had hidden six bodies of women he had strangled and killed.<ref name="crimezzz">[http://www.crimezzz.net/serialkillers/M/MFEKA_samuel_bongani.php Fiche de Bongani Mfeka] sur Serial Killer News.</ref>
His first murder was in 1993. The last body was found on September 8, 1996, in a state of advanced decomposition. According to police, four bodies were found between his home and around KwaZulu-Natal. Mfeka was also questioned about the fifteen bodies left behind by the [[Nasrec strangler]], although he was not officially accused.

{{Infobox serial killer |name=Elifasi Msomi |image= |image_size= |caption= |birth_name=Elifasi Msomi |alias=The Axe Killer
Tokoloshe Killer |birth_date= 1910 |birth_place=[[South Africa]] |death_date=Feb 10, 1956 |death_place=[[Pretoria Central Prison]] in [[Pretoria]], [[Gauteng]], [[South Africa]] |cause=[[Hanging]] |victims=15 |country=[[South Africa]] |states= |beginyear=1953 |endyear=1955 |apprehended=1955 |penalty=[[Capital punishment|Death Sentence]] }} '''Elifasi Msomi''' a.k.a. '''The Axe Killer''' (1910--1953) was a [[South Africa]]n [[serial killer]] who was convicted in 1955 of 15 murders and sentenced to [[Death sentence|death]] by [[hanging]]. His victims all came from the [[Umkomaas]] and Umzimkulu valleys of [[KwaZulu-Natal]]. A [[Zulu people|Zulu]] man, Msomi was an unsuccessful young [[sangoma]] (shaman). Seeking professional assistance, he consulted with another sangoma. Msomi claims that during this exchange he was co-opted by an evil spirit, a [[Tikoloshe|tokoloshe]]. In August 1953, under the instruction of the tokoloshe, Msomi began an 18-month killing spree in the southern [[KwaZulu-Natal]] valleys of [[South Africa]].{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,808161,00.html|title=Foreign News: Tilcoloshe's Friend|author=|date=20 February 1956|publisher=|via=www.time.com}} Msomi initially raped and murdered a young woman in the presence of his mistress, whose blood he kept in a bottle. Unimpressed with his 'new' powers, his mistress alerted the police who arrested Msomi. He escaped shortly afterwards, giving credit for his escape to the all-powerful tokoloshe. Msomi returned to his murderous ways, killing five children before being re-arrested. He duly escaped again. Msomi was arrested a month later for petty theft. The stolen items turned out to belong to his victims and he was soon identified as the murderous culprit. Msomi readily assisted the police in finding some of his victims' remains, including a missing skull. Whether he gained further satisfaction from revisiting his crime scenes or felt [[diminished responsibility]] in light of the tokoloshe's influence is unclear. During his trial, Msomi claimed that he was merely a conduit for the evil tokoloshe. Two psychologists disagreed, stating that Msomi was in fact of much higher than average intelligence and further that he derived sexual pleasure from inflicting pain.{{cite web|url=http://www.truecrimelibrary.co.uk/crime_series_show.php?id=557&series_number=13|title=''True Crime Libraries'' : Worldwide Hangings.|author=|date=|website=truecrimelibrary.co.uk}}{{dead link|date=July 2017|fix-attempted=yes}} Msomi was sentenced to death by hanging at Pretoria Central Prison. Msomi's reference to the tokoloshe and his numerous escapes had however caused a high level of consternation amongst some of the [[Zulu people|Zulu]] community. Upon request, the judge permitted a deputation of nine Zulu Chiefs and Elders to attend the hanging in order to confirm that the tokoloshe did in fact not save Msomi from his death. Even so, one chief felt that Msomi might return after death as a tokoloshe himself. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Msomi, Elifasi}} [[Category:1956 deaths]] [[Category:South African serial killers]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:Executed South African people]] [[Category:People executed by South Africa by hanging]] [[Category:20th-century executions by South Africa]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by South Africa]] [[Category:South African people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Axe murder]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Executed serial killers]] [[Category:Escapees from South African detention]] [[Category:South African escapees]] [[Category:Zulu people]] [[Category:Crimes involving Satanism or the occult]]

{{short description|South African serial murderer}} {{Infobox serial killer | name = Mukosi Freddy Mulaudzi | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | alias = "The Limpopo Serial Killer" | birth_date = 1962 | birth_place = Maelula, [[Limpopo]], [[South Africa]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder]] | sentence = 11 life sentences | victims = 13 | beginyear = 1990 | endyear = 2006 | country = [[South Africa]] | states = [[Limpopo]] | apprehended = July 2006 | imprisoned = }}
'''Mukosi Freddy Mulaudzi''' (born 1962 in Maelula, [[Limpopo]]), also known as '''The Limpopo Serial Killer''', is a [[South Africa]]n robber, rapist and [[serial killer]] who murdered a total of 13 people from 1990 to 2006, until his capture in July 2006.<ref name=post>{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/limpopo-serial-killer-case-postponed-297239|title=Limpopo serial killer case postponed|work=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]]|date=11 October 2006}}</ref> He was given 11 life sentences for his crimes.
==Murders== Mulaudzi, who was initially imprisoned for two separate murders and an armed robbery committed in 1990, managed to break out of the Baviaanspoort Prison in [[Pretoria]] in 1996. Ever since then, he started committing crimes, beginning in 2004. During that year, he attempted to murder thrice, broke into houses two times, committed two armed robberies and assaults twice, all committed in the Siloam and [[Levubu]] areas.<ref name=post/><ref name=bribe>{{cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Cops-offered-me-R100-000-20061123|title='Cops offered me R100 000'|author=Nkosana ka Makaula and Nyambeni Mandiwana|work=[[News24]]|date=23 November 2006}}</ref>
Onwards, from 2005 to 2006, he started committing violent murders, and among his victims were: * 19-year-old Ndivhuwo Winnity Tshilimandila, who was raped before being killed, as well as her three cousins: Nyadzeni (14), Shumani (10) and Levhalesani Maxwell Sivhugwana (7), who were all hacked to death at their home in [[Thohoyandou]].<ref name=post/><ref name=bribe/> * 30-year-old Phophi Tracy Radzilani, killed with a sharp object in her house, as well as her children, Rotondwa (7) and Moses Mushiana (5), who were burned alive in their bedroom in Tshedza village. Household items were also stolen.<ref name=post/><ref name=bribe/> * Shonisani Thinandavha, killed in July 2006 at Mulodi, who had her breast, right hand, left ear and upper lip sliced off.<ref name=hid>{{cite news|url=https://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2008-08-19-escaped-killer-hid-in-unused-fridge/|title=escaped killer hid in unused fridge|newspaper=[[The Sowetan|Sowetan LIVE]]|date=19 August 2008}}</ref>
Soon after killing Thinandavha, Mulaudzi was captured by police while trying to hide in an unused refrigerator.<ref name=hid/> ==Trial and sentence== In October 2006, Mulaudzi briefly appeared before the court, but his case was moved to November 15, as new charges were connected to him by authorities, according to Superintendent Motlafela Mojapelo.<ref name=post/> Mulaudzi refused to confess and often caused scenes in the courtroom; in one instance, threatening to sleep during the proceedings if his wife, Takalani Florence Nethengwe (charged with possession of stolen goods), and son were not released, and in another, alleged that the police investigator had bribed him with money and phone cards so he would confess.<ref name=bribe/><ref name=hid/> Eventually, he was convicted of the most charges, with Judge Godfrey Hetisani giving him 11 sentences. ==References== {{reflist}}
